[[Sydney]] |startdate = 24 November |enddate = 17 December 1968 |stages = 31 |stagekm = |overallkm = 16000 |surface = [[Tarmacadam|Tarmac]] and Gravel |driver1 = {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Andrew Cowan]]
{{flagicon|GBR}} Colin Malkin
{{flagicon|GBR}} Brian Coyle |team1 = {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Rootes Group|Rootes Motor Group]] |teamsstart = 98 |teamsfinish = 56 }} The '''1968 London–Sydney Marathon''', officially '''Daily Express-Daily Telegraph London-Sydney Marathon''' was the first running of the [[London-Sydney Marathon]]. The rally took place between the 24th of November and the 17th of December 1968. The event covered 9,900 miles (16,000 km) through [[Europe]], [[Asia]] and [[Australia]]. It was won by [[Andrew Cowan]], Colin Malkin and Brian Coyle, driving a [[Rootes Arrow|Hillman Hunter]]. ==Background== The original Marathon was the result of a lunch in late 1967, during a period of despondency in Britain caused by the [[devaluation]] of the [[Pound sterling|pound]].[http://marathon68.homestead.com/Page3.html "How It All Began"], transcript of contemporary ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' report, marathon68.homestead.com[http://www.citroen.mb.ca/cItROeNeT/sport/london-sydney-marathon-68.html "The great adventure of the decade"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207051259/http://www.citroen.mb.ca/cItROeNeT/sport/london-sydney-marathon-68.html |date=7 December 2006 }}, Julian Marsh, Citroënët, 1996 [[Sir Max Aitken, 2nd Baronet|Sir Max Aitken]], proprietor of the ''[[Daily Express]]'', and two of his editorial executives, Jocelyn Stevens and [[Tommy Sopwith (racing driver)|Tommy Sopwith]], decided to create an event which their newspaper could sponsor, and which would serve to raise the country's spirits. Such an event would, it was felt, act as a showcase for British engineering and would boost export sales in the countries through which it passed. The initial UK£10,000 winner's prize offered by the ''Daily Express'' was soon joined by a £3,000 runners-up award and two £2,000 prizes for the third-placed team and for the highest-placed Australians, all of which were underwritten by the ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|Daily Telegraph]]'' newspaper and its proprietor [[Sir Frank Packer]], who was eager to promote the Antipodean leg of the rally. ==The route== An eight-man organising committee was established to create a suitably challenging but navigable route. [[Jack Sears]], organising secretary and himself a former racing driver, plotted a 7,000-mile course covering eleven countries in as many days, and arranged that the [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company|P&O]] liner ''S.S. Chusan'' would ferry the first 72 cars and their crews on the nine-day voyage from India, before the final 2,900 miles across Australia:[http://marathon68.homestead.com/Page15.html "Timetable of the Marathon"], marathon68.homestead.com[http://marathon68.homestead.com/Page6.html "The Route"], Alan Sawyer, marathon68.homestead.com {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" ! colspan=6 align=right | Europe and Asia |- ! style="width:2em" | Leg ! style="width:12em" | Date ! style="width:5em" | Start ! style="width:5em" | Finish ! style="width:5em" | Allowed time ! style="width:45em" | Description |- | 1 | 24–25 November | London | Paris | 12h 32m | 2300hrs depart [[Crystal Palace, London]]; {{other uses|99 (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{subprime mortgage crisis sidebar}} '''99ers''' is a colloquial term for unemployed people in the United States, mostly citizens, who have exhausted all of their [[unemployment benefits]], including all [[unemployment extension]]s. As a result of the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]] passed by [[United States Congress|Congress]] in February 2009, many unemployed people could receive up to 99 weeks of unemployment insurance benefits, hence the name "99ers".<ref name="99ers1">{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/12/AR2010071205144.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Michael A. | last=Fletcher | title=No unemployment extension: Benefits not in sight for the long-term jobless | date=July 13, 2010}}</ref><ref name="99ers2">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/37404685/ns/business-economy_at_a_crossroads MSNBC News], MSNBC Article on "99ers"</ref><ref name="99ers3">{{cite news | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/30/business/la-fi-0430-99ers-20100430 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Alana | last=Semuels | title='99Ers' Exhaust Jobless Benefits | date=April 30, 2010}}</ref><ref name="99ers4">[http://www.aolnews.com/article/2010-unemployment-extension-faq-tier-5-99ers-explained-and-de/19555874 AOL News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817165752/http://www.aolnews.com/article/2010-unemployment-extension-faq-tier-5-99ers-explained-and-de/19555874 |date=August 17, 2010 }}, AOL News Article on "99ers"</ref><ref name="99ers5">[http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/99ers-left-benefits-extension-11203881 ABC News], ABC News Video on "99ers"</ref><ref name="99ers6">[http://www.epi.org/publications/entry/for_four_out_of_five_unemployed_workers_there_are_no_jobs/ Economics Policy Institute], EPI article on "99ers"</ref> An estimated 7 million people are affected.<ref name="99ers7">[http://globaleconomicanalysis.blogspot.com/2010/09/question-of-day-how-many-people-have.html], Mike Shedlock's blog, describing estimation methodology</ref>
==Unemployment benefits==
United States unemployment benefits during the [[financial crisis of 2007-2010]] were calculated as follows (with the availability of extensions dependent on a state's unemployment rate (see: [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]]):
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Unemployment Benefits !! # of Weeks |- | Regular Unemployment Insurance Benefits ||align=center| 26<ref name="regular">[http://www.labor.ny.gov/ui/claimantinfo/ExtendedBenefits.shtm NY Dept. of Labor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812093504/http://www.labor.ny.gov/ui/claimantinfo/extendedbenefits.shtm |date=August 12, 2010 }}, Unemployment Benefits Info</ref> |- | Emergency Unemployment Compensation Tier 1 ||align=center| 20<ref name="eucweeks">[http://ows.doleta.gov/unemploy/pdf/euc08.pdf U.S. Dept. of Labor], Emergency Unemployment Compensation (EUC) Program PDF</ref> |- | Emergency Unemployment Compensation Tier 2 ||align=center| 14<ref name="eucweeks" /> |- | Emergency Unemployment Compensation Tier 3 ||align=center| 13<ref name="eucweeks" /> |- | Emergency Unemployment Compensation Tier 4 ||align=center| 6<ref name="eucweeks" /> |- | Extended Benefits (13 weeks + 7 additional) ||align=center| 20<ref name="ebweeks">[http://ows.doleta.gov/unemploy/extenben.asp U.S. Dept. of Labor], Unemployment Insurance Extended Benefits</ref> |- | '''Total Number of Weeks''' ||align=center| '''99''' |}
==Legislation==
Legislation to extend unemployment benefits had been blocked from coming to a vote on the floor of the Senate through minority Republican [[filibuster]] or holds. This began in February 2010 with the block of an unemployment benefit funding bill vote for already authorized and granted unemployment checks for those who had not exhausted their benefits by a single Senator, [[Jim Bunning]] (R-KY).<ref>[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0210/33566.html Politico], Sen. Jim Bunning holds floor, Politico (February 2010)</ref>
Following that [[precedent]], Senate floor votes on unemployment have required a [[supermajority]] of sixty votes to bring the bills to the floor. Bunning's position was that he wanted the bill paid for out of previously allocated funds from the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]]. Senators who did not initially support Bunning's position since used this argument to block or delay votes on unemployment extensions that could not achieve a supermajority to reach the floor for a vote.<ref>[http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/economy-a-budget/111057-unemployment-extension-should-have-been-paid-for-sen-mike-johanns The Hill], Unemployment extension should have been paid for (Sen. Mike Johanns) The Hill</ref>
Economists have cited that unemployment should not have the requirement of being paid for out of an existing stimulus package because it is stimulative and, therefore, to take away allocated funds from other projects would have a self-canceling effect.<ref name='cbpp'>[http://www.cbpp.org/cms/?fa=view&id=863 Center on Budget and Policy Priorities ], The Four Pieces of Effective Fiscal Stimulus Unemployment Insurance, State Relief, Food Stamps, and Tax Refunds, Center on Budget and Policy Priorities</ref>
The passage of the bill to fund eligible (non-exhausted) unemployment benefits required a special appointment of a replacement senator, [[Carte Goodwin]], by [[West Virginia]] Governor [[Joe Manchin]], after the death of Senator [[Robert Byrd]] (D-WV), whose vote was needed for the supermajority. This gave the Senate its 60th vote for the legislation and the funds were released to the states to pay unemployment compensation to those who were eligible and who had not yet exhausted benefits as of July 2010.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100726004940/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100722/ap_on_bi_ge/us_unemployment_benefits Associated Press], Checks are coming: Obama signs unemployment bill, AP (22 July 2010)</ref>
The passage of the bill did not provide for those who exhausted their benefits, the 99ers.
On August 4, 2010, [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Debbie Stabenow]] (D-MI) introduced a bill (S.3706) to extend unemployment past 99 weeks. The bill was referred to the [[Senate Finance Committee]] prior to the Senate breaking for their summer vacation:
===The Americans Want to Work Act (S.3706)===
A Senate bill introduced by Senator Debbie Stabenow (D-MI) on August 4, 2010 will, if passed, benefit those who have exhausted all of their benefits by providing an additional 20 weeks of unemployment benefits under a Tier 5. The bill has an unemployment rate threshold of 7.5% which requires states to have an unemployment rate at 7.5% or higher to qualify. The bill was announced by Senator Stabenow on [[MSNBC]]'s ''The [[Ed Schultz]] Show'' [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/38584698#38565782 (video)].<ref name="ed">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/38584698#38565782 The Ed Shultz Show], MSNBC News, Senator Stabenow Announces 99er Bill</ref> The bill is co-sponsored by Senators [[Charles Schumer]] (D-NY), [[Harry Reid]] (D-NV), [[Dick Durbin]] (D-IL), [[Carl Levin]] (D-MI), [[Bob Casey, Jr.]] (D-PA), [[Christopher Dodd]] (D-CT), [[Sherrod Brown]] (D-OH), [[Jack Reed (politician)|Jack Reed]] (D-RI), and [[Sheldon Whitehouse]] (D-RI).<ref name="S.3706 Senator Stabenow Official Press Release">[http://stabenow.senate.gov/press/2010/080410Americanswanttoworkact.htm S.3706 Senator Stabenow Press Release] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819062613/http://stabenow.senate.gov/press/2010/080410Americanswanttoworkact.htm |date=August 19, 2010 }}, S.3706 Senator Stabenow Press Release</ref>
The proposed bill was designed to help 99ers by: * Creating an additional tier of benefits for those who have exhausted their unemployment insurance. * Extends the HIRE Act payroll tax exemption through the end of 2011. * Doubles the general business tax credit to encourage businesses to hire the hardest hit Americans.
Tier 5 Unemployment Insurance (Under S.3706 Bill): What it does: Provides 20 weeks of additional unemployment insurance for states with 7.5% or higher unemployment. This tier will benefit the people who have exhausted all of their benefits.
Retroactive Eligibility: Would apply retroactively to everyone who has exhausted all of their previous tiers in recent months. However, benefits would not be paid retroactively. (Example: a claimant who exhausted his or her benefits three months ago would be eligible to begin Tier 5 at the date of enactment. He or she would not, however, be paid out for the three months in which no benefits were received. If a claimant is going to exhaust benefits in two weeks, he or she will move right onto Tier 5 and receive 20 weeks of benefits.)
Requirements: People who are unemployed still need to meet current UI law requirements such as job searches.
On August 10, 2010, Representative [[Shelley Berkley]] (D-NV) introduced a House bill (H.R. 6901) to extend benefits for another 20 additional weeks for states whose unemployment rate exceeds 10 percent:
===The Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act (H.R. 6091)=== A House bill introduced by Representative [[Shelley Berkley]] (D-NV-1) on August 10, 2010 will, if passed, benefit those who have exhausted all of their benefits by providing an additional 20 weeks of unemployment benefits under a Tier 5. The bill has an unemployment rate threshold of 10% which requires states to have an unemployment rate at 10% or higher to qualify. The bill is co-sponsored by Representatives [[Michael F. Doyle]] (D, PA-14), [[Bob Filner]] (D, CA-51), [[Barney Frank]] (D, MA-4), [[Phil Hare]] (D, IL-17), [[Dale Kildee]] (D, MI-5), [[Carolyn Kilpatrick]] (D, MI-13), [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]] (D, GA-5), [[Jim McDermott]] (D, WA-7), [[Laura Richardson]] (D, CA-37), [[Linda Sánchez]] (D, CA-39), [[Janice Schakowsky]] (D, IL-9) and [[Diane Watson]] (D, CA-33).<ref name="H.R. 6091 Open Congress">[http://berkley.house.gov/2010/08/new-berkley-bill-extends-unemployment-help-to-nevadans-who-have-exhausted-benefits.shtml Berkley.House.Gov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101007050130/http://berkley.house.gov/2010/08/new-berkley-bill-extends-unemployment-help-to-nevadans-who-have-exhausted-benefits.shtml |date=October 7, 2010 }}, Shelly Berkley (H.R. 6091) Press Release</ref>
==Media coverage in 2010== CNN did a series of stories regarding 99ers.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NoEiz-sqeg0</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=79RFghjels0</ref>
News reports and interviews have been presented by various media outlets that include ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]'s ''NewsHour''. The 99er cause has been championed by [[Ed Schultz]] on his MSNBC television show, where he lashed out at Congress, and hosted the announcement of Senator Stabenow's 99er bill on his MSNBC television show [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/38584698#38565782 (video)]<ref name="ed"/> and his radio program<ref>[http://www.bigeddieradio.com/videoblog/details.asp?BID=353 The Ed Schultz Radio Show] The Ed Schultz Radio Show's Stabenow Announcement on 99ers, August 4, 2010</ref> and by [[Rachel Maddow]] on her television program where she replayed [[99ers#Controversy|negative statements]] about the unemployed by [[Sharron Angle]], Senator [[Jon Kyl]] (R-AZ), Rep. [[Steve King]], (R-IA), Rep. [[Dean Heller]] (R-NV), Lt. Gov. [[Andre Bauer]] (R-SC). Examiner
Both ''The New York Times'' and [[PBS NewsHour]] have covered the story.<ref name="99ers10">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/03/us/03unemployed.html | work=The New York Times | first=Michael | last=Luo | title=Desperation Grows as Jobless Benefits Run Out | date=August 2, 2010}}</ref><ref name="99ers11">[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/business/july-dec10/99ers_08-06.html PBS NewsHour], PBS Video on "99ers"</ref>
On July 19, 2010, ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' published "Get America Back to Work" which has gathered signatures<ref name="sigs">[http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-08-13/the-daily-beast-manifesto/ "Get America Back to Work"] ''The Daily Beast'', 100 Signatures</ref> of prominent economists, academics, journalists and historians, including five [[Nobel Prize]] [[Laureate]]s, in support of a statement calling for further stimulus to deal with long-term unemployment, citing [[Keynesian economics]] in support of their position:<ref name="Daily Beast">[http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-07-19/save-the-economy-a-manifesto-by-harry-evans-joseph-stiglitz-alan-blinder-and-other-leaders/ The Daily Beast], ''Get America Back to Work'', The Daily Beast</ref> The article was signed by one hundred prominent economists, historians, academics and journalists,<ref name="sigs"/> including: [[Joseph Stiglitz]], [[Alan Blinder]], [[John Cassidy (journalist)|John Cassidy]], [[Lizabeth Cohen]], [[Jim Hoge]], [[Robert Reich]], [[Richard Parker (economist)|Richard Parker]], [[Laura Tyson]], Sir [[Harold Evans]], [[Sean Wilentz]], [[Kenneth Arrow]], [[Peter Beinart]], [[Sidney Blumenthal]], [[Nancy Folbre]], [[Simon Schama]] and [[Robert Solow]] ([http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-08-13/the-daily-beast-manifesto/ list]).<ref name="sigs"/>
On August 15, 2010, ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' ([[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]) published an article entitled "They're Known as 'the 99ers,' and their numbers are growing in Ohio and nationwide".<ref>[http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2010/08/theyre_known_as_the_99ers_and.html ''The Plain Dealer''], They're known as 'the 99ers,' and their numbers are growing in Ohio and nationwide, The Plain Dealer</ref>
In December 2010 the BBC ran a story about the 99ers titled "What happens when your unemployment benefits stop?" The article included the views of [[Heidi Shierholz]] "We can kick people off and it will certainly make people more desperate to find a job. But in a labour market like this it's not going to make them more likely to find a job because the jobs aren't there." <ref>{{cite news | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-11894634 | work= BBC| first=Rajini | last=Vaidyanathan| title=What happens when your unemployment benefits stop | date=December 6, 2010}}</ref>
==Controversy==
Republican legislators insisted that additional unemployment benefits be paid for out of existing funds. This is a departure from how unemployment benefits have been funded in the past.<ref name="cbpp"/>
Democratic supporters of additional unemployment extensions {{Who|date=June 2011}} have pointed out that Republicans who are calling for unemployment benefits to be paid for out of existing funds are, in some cases, the same legislators who insist the [[Bush tax cuts]] be renewed without funding. Republicans have countered the Bush tax cuts are stimulative and therefore do not require funding.<ref name="gma">[http://blogs.abcnews.com/george/2010/07/bachmann-pay-for-unemployment-benefits-not-tax-cuts.html ABC News], Bachmann: Pay for Unemployment Benefits, Not Tax Cuts, ABC News (July 2010)</ref>
The requirement of a supermajority to bring bills to the floor has led to heated and controversial comments, including this exchange between Senators [[Jim Bunning]] (R-KY) and [[Jeff Merkley]] (D-OR), where Senator Merkley asked Senator Bunning to stop his repeated blocks of a unanimous consent motion to extend unemployment benefits, to which Senator Bunning replied: "Tough shit."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/02/26/jim-bunning-repeatedly-bl_n_477910.html Huffington Post (26 February 2010), Politico], Jim Bunning Repeatedly Blocks Unemployment Benefits Extension, Huffington Post, Politico</ref>
Several other politicians, lawmakers and commentators have made controversial statements portraying the long-term unemployed as lazy, unwilling to work, and/or on drugs,<ref name="wm">[http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/archives/individual/2010_06/024378.php Washington Monthly], Washington Monthly: "Republicans Don't Like the Unemployed"</ref> while some in favor of long term unemployment benefits have called opponents pro-death and pro-child hunger.
* [[Orrin Hatch]] proposed an amendment that would require unemployment beneficiaries to pass a drug test to qualify for programs: "Drugs are a scourge on our society – hurting children, families and communities alike. This amendment is a way to help people get off of drugs to become productive and healthy members of society, while ensuring that valuable taxpayer dollars aren’t wasted.”<ref>[http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/103357-hatch-wants-drug-tests-for-recipients-of-federal-benefits Sen. Hatch wants unemployed to face mandatory drug tests], Sen. Hatch wants unemployed to face mandatory drug tests, The Hill</ref> * [[Glenn Beck]]: "Some of [the 99ers] I – frankly, I bet, should be ashamed to call them Americans"<ref>[http://www.lexisnexis.com.stlcopisa.stlcop.edu/hottopics/lnacademic LexisNexis BECK for August 16, 2010]</ref> * [[Alan Grayson]]: "I will say this to Republicans who will block this [unemployement benefits extension] bill now for months, and kept food out of the mouths of children. I will say to them now, may God have mercy on your souls." <ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rep-alan-grayson/final-score-compassion-1_b_657491.html Huffington Post], Alan Grayson: Final Score: Compassion 1, Bullying 0</ref> * [[Sharron Angle]]: "“You can make more money on unemployment than you can going down and getting one of those jobs that is an honest job, but it doesn’t pay as much. And so that’s what’s happened to us is that we have put in so much entitlement into our government that we really have spoiled our citizenry and said you don’t want the jobs that are available.” <ref>[http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/06/23/republicans-to-the-unemployed-youre-lazy/ Republicans to the Unemployed: You're Lazy], Republicans to the Unemployed: You're Lazy, Politics Daily</ref> * [[Rand Paul]]: "As bad as it sounds, ultimately we do have to sometimes accept a wage that's less than we had at our previous job in order to get back to work and allow the economy to get started again. Nobody likes that, but it may be one of the tough love things that has to happen." <ref name="refhill">[http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/gop-primaries/109443-dems-seize-on-gop-candidates-comments-about-unemployed Dems seize on GOP candidates' comments about unemployed], Dems seize on GOP candidates' comments about unemployed, The Hill</ref> * [[Tom Corbett]]: "People don’t want to come back to work while they still have some unemployment. That’s becoming a problem. The jobs are there, but if we keep extending unemployment, people are just going to sit there."<ref name="refhill"/> * [[Rush Limbaugh]]: "Extended unemployment benefits do nothing but incentivize people not to look for work"<ref>''The Rush Limbaugh Show'', June 29, 2010.</ref>
On May 24, 2010, [[Cynthia Tucker]] of the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'', published: ''Unemployment benefits make people lazy? Not so'', where she reported how the economist [[Mark Zandi]] cited the lack of available jobs<ref name="epi"/> in response to a statement by Senator [[Judd Gregg]] (R-NH) that unemployment benefits discouraged the unemployed from looking for work.<ref name="ajc">[http://blogs.ajc.com/cynthia-tucker/2010/05/24/unemployment-benefits-make-people-lazy-not-so The Atlanta Journal-Constitution] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529181119/http://blogs.ajc.com/cynthia-tucker/2010/05/24/unemployment-benefits-make-people-lazy-not-so/ |date=May 29, 2010 }}, Unemployment benefits make people lazy? Not so, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</ref>
Several prominent economists have argued long term unemployment benefits are an incentive not to work, including President Obama's former White House economic adviser [[Lawrence Summers]], who once wrote in the Concise Encyclopedia of Economics: "The second way government assistance programs contribute to long-term unemployment is by providing an incentive, and the means, not to work. Each unemployed person has a 'reservation wage' — the minimum wage he or she insists on getting before accepting a job." <ref name="econlib">[http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/Unemployment.html Library of Economics and Liberty], Concise Encyclopedia of Economics</ref> A [[Brookings Institution]] panel on economic activity said in March 2010 that jobless insurance extensions "correspond to between 0.7 and 1.8 percentage points of the 5.5 percentage point increase in the unemployment rate witnessed in the current recession." Alan Reynolds of the [[Cato Institute]] found nearly two percent of the current jobless rate is due to extensions of unemployment insurance and other federal policies.<ref name="wsj">[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303828304575180243952375172 Wall Street Journal], Incentives Not to Work</ref>
99ers have responded to these and similar statements with their own stories of repeated and unsuccessful job hunting efforts where the number of applicants have far exceeded the available positions.<ref name="99ers11"/> The Economic Policy Institute's data supports the 99ers' and Mark Zandi's position in their March 2010 report of an average of five applicants for each opening.<ref name="epi">[http://www.epi.org/publications/entry/job_openings_improve_but_still_more_than_5_unemployed_workers_per_avai/ Economic Policy Institute], EPI 5 applicants for each job stats</ref>
The [[Economic Policy Institute]], using data provided by the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]], has verified that, as of September 2010, the U.S. economy would need to add 11.5 million jobs to make up for the shortfall due to the recession. In September 2010, the private sector added 64,000 jobs.<ref name="epi1">[http://www.epi.org/publications/entry/september_jobs_picture/ Fifteen months since recession’s official end, economy short 11.5 million jobs], Fifteen months since recession’s official end, economy short 11.5 million jobs, Economic Policy Institute</ref>{{Update inline|date=November 2015}}
==Hiring==
Proponents of benefits extension point out that corporations are sitting on approximately 1.8 trillion in cash while not hiring.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Business/hoarding-hiring-corporations-stockpile-mountain-cash/story?id=10250559 ABC News Report], Hoarding, Not Hiring – Corporations Stockpile Mountain of Cash – ABC News</ref> [[MSNBC]] reported in June 2010, that, for 99ers, a job can feel like a mirage:<ref>[http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37404685/ns/business-economy_at_a_crossroads/ MSNBC News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806230103/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/37404685/ns/business-economy_at_a_crossroads/ |date=August 6, 2010 }}, MSNBC News, For 99ers, a job can seem like a mirage</ref> The Economic Policy Institute's March 2010 report cites an average of five applicants for each job opening.<ref name="epi"/>
==Discrimination==
Job postings with statements that only workers who are currently employed or those who've been unemployed for less than six months will be considered – thereby decreasing opportunities for the long-term unemployed – have been documented. ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', which has chronicled the phenomenon by combing through online employment listings on sites such as [[Craigslist]] and [[Monster.com]], has found multiple listings that use the terms: "Must be currently employed, "no unemployed applicants will be considered" or "must have been employed within the last 6 months." <ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/22/this-week-in-jobless-disc_n_772571.html This Week In Jobless Discrimination: Unemployed Applicants Might 'Be Tempted To Steal'], This Week in Jobless Discrimination: Unemployed Applicants Might 'Be Tempted To Steal', The Huffington Post</ref>
An employment recruiter for the search firm Goodwin and Associates told ''The Huffington Post'' that "some companies think that the best people are already working" and "Maybe the ones looking for jobs for some reason had a problem, or were let go for a reason, or quit for a reason, but the people companies want are the type that already have a job."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/08/employers-continue-to-dis_n_756136.html Employers Continue to Discriminate Against Jobless, Think 'The Best People Are Already Working], Employers Continue to Discriminate Against Jobless, Think 'The Best People Are Already Working, The Huffington Post</ref>
Statistics provided by the Economic Policy Institute and the Bureau of Labor Statistics indicate the majority of long-term unemployed who lost their jobs due to the recession have been let go through no fault of their own in mass lay-offs that were cited by their companies as having been for economic reasons.<ref name="epi1"/>
The exclusionary jobs postings have prompted [[New Jersey]] Assemblyman Peter Barnes (D-[[Middlesex, New Jersey|Middlesex]]) to propose legislation that would impose fines of $10,000 per incident for companies that post job advertisements which say the unemployed shouldn't bother applying.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/13/new-law-proposed-in-new-j_n_761570.html Proposed New Jersey Law Would Penalize Employers For Discriminating Against Unemployed], Proposed New Jersey Law Would Penalize Employers For Discriminating Against Unemployed, The Huffington Post</ref>
The [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] has released a report on the long-term experience of the jobless<ref name="bls">[http://www.bls.gov/opub/ils/pdf/opbils82.pdf BLS (PDF)], Bureau of Labor Statistics, Long-term unemployment experience of the jobless</ref> which states that, while more younger workers were unemployed, the [[Ageism#Employment|older worker]] was the most impacted by long-term unemployment, leading to concerns that ageism may factor in hiring discrimination.<ref name="bls"/>
==Americans with disabilities, and the long-term unemployed==
As [[Political positions of Hillary Clinton|Hillary Clinton]] asserted during the summer of 2015, "a quarter-century after passage of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] in 1990, it often remains difficult for [[persons with disabilities]] to gain access to meaningful and gainful employment". Many, become "99ers", as they continue to be left out of the workforce, and for those who are employed, many are in under-stimulating jobs that don't fully utilize their talents and abilities".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hillaryclinton.com/issues/disability-rights/ |title=HillaryClinton.com - Issues - Disability Rights |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=July 26, 2015 |website=hillaryclinton.com |publisher=hillaryclinton.com |access-date=November 7, 2015 |quote="Now, 25 years after the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act ... there is still much work to do, including improving access to meaningful and gainful employment for people with disabilities. Too many Americans with disabilities continue to be left out of the workforce, and for those who are employed, too many are in under-stimulating jobs that don't fully allow them to use their talents."}}</ref> Her major primary challenger, [[Political positions of Bernie Sanders|Bernie Sanders]], the current U.S. Senator from Vermont, has also raised this issue as a major concern, stating in the summer of 2015: "the real unemployment rate is much higher than [[Bureau of Labor Statistics|the 'official' figure]] typically reported in the newspapers. When you include workers who have given up looking for jobs, or those who are working part time when they want to work full time, the real number is much higher than official figures would suggest."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://berniesanders.com/issues/creating-decent-paying-jobs/ |title=Bernie 2016 - Issues - Creating Decent Paying Jobs |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=berniesanders.com |access-date=2015-11-17 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118023313/http://berniesanders.com/issues/creating-decent-paying-jobs/ |archivedate=November 18, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref>
==Organizing==
The 99ers have begun to organize, both online and in rallies. 99ers have testified before Congress<ref>[http://washingtonindependent.com/86700/as-long-term-unemployment-deepens-99ers-look-for-answers Washington Independent] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728082557/http://washingtonindependent.com/86700/as-long-term-unemployment-deepens-99ers-look-for-answers |date=July 28, 2010 }}, Washington Independent, As Long Term Unemployment Deepens, 99ers Look for Answers</ref> and have started numerous online sites from which to organize, meet others in their situation<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/04/09/unemployed-friends-jobles_n_532077.html Huffington Post], Unemployed Friends: Jobless Find Support Online, Huffington Post</ref> and to share links to resources.
A rally sponsored by Unemployed Workers Action Group (UWAG.org)<ref name="99ers">{{cite news | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/08/08/2010-08-08_99ers_looking_for_help_a_curse_becomes_a_cause_as_jobless_benefits_expire.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | first=Lore | last=Croghan | title='99ers' looking for help, plan to hold rally on Wall St. to demand unemployment benefits | date=August 7, 2010}}</ref> took place on [[Wall Street]] in New York City on August 12, 2010 to support the S.3706 Tier 5 unemployment extension bill. It was held at [[Federal Hall National Memorial]], at 26 Wall Street in New York City.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/08/12/2010-08-12_new_yorks_jobless_99ers_channel_anger_in_wall_street_protest_demand_unemployment.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | first=Lore | last=Croghan | title=New York's jobless 99ers channel anger in Wall Street protest, demand unemployment extension | date=August 12, 2010}}</ref> and was attended by MSNBC's Ed Schultz and NYC's Labor Commission Representative, John Noyes:<ref name="nydol">[http://laborbuzz.labor.ny.gov/?p=2576 New York Labor Commission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100814004659/http://laborbuzz.labor.ny.gov/?p=2576 |date=August 14, 2010 }}, Takin' It to the Streets, John Noyes, NY Labor Commission Website</ref>
{{quote|Today on Wall Street, people who have been out of work for nearly two years rallied to ask: where's the recovery for the Middle Class? Today, I attended a rally of professional Americans who have been displaced by corporate greed and out-of-touch politicians; a passionate crowd of 99ers rallied at the Federal Hall, here in New York, in the shadow of Wall Street. They had one basic question: Where are the jobs? I'd like to tell these people that Washington is listening, but the reality is that members of Congress are back home trying to save their own jobs. You can see the passion in the eyes of the 99ers today. They just want a chance to work. That's it.|source=Ed Schultz, MSNBC's ''The Ed Show'' – [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/38683246#38683246 Video].<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/38683246#38683246 MSNBC],'' The Ed Show'' (Video)</ref>}}
On September 16, 2010 a coalition of numerous 99er activist groups was formed to become one large united force to lobby Washington to pass legislation that would add weeks of benefits for all those who had exhausted all benefits without yet finding a job. They called themselves the American 99ers Union<ref>[http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2010/09/long-term_jobless_lobby_congre.html ''The Plain Dealer''], Jobless Americans lobby Congress for extended benefits</ref> and have held a number of campaigns in which they encouraged thousands of 99er activists to fax, call and email Congress in support of a Tier 5 or other method of adding extended benefits for 99ers.<ref>[http://www.prlog.org/11064903-the-american-99ers-union-urges-washington-dc-to-save-america-now.html PRLog], The American 99ers Union Urges Washington, D.C. to Save America Now</ref>
Also independent web-sites like http://fileunemployment.org/ and others have sprung up to help 99ers.

{{About|Robert Bolt's play}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox play | name = A Man for All Seasons | image = A Man For All Seasons Prog 1960.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Programme from the original London production (1960) | writer = [[Robert Bolt]] | characters = The Common Man
Sir Thomas More
The Duke of Norfolk
Thomas Cromwell
King Henry VIII
Margaret More
William Roper
Cardinal Thomas Wolsey
Alice More
Thomas Cranmer
Richard Rich
Signor Chapuys | setting = Sixteenth century England | premiere = 1 July 1960 (London) | place = [[Gielgud Theatre|Globe Theatre]] | orig_lang = English | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''A Man for All Seasons''''' is a play by [[Robert Bolt]] based on the life of [[Sir Thomas More]]. An early form of the play had been written for [[BBC Radio]] in 1954, and a one-hour live television version starring [[Bernard Hepton]] was produced in 1957 by the BBC,[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1667059/ "''A Man for All Seasons'' Listing"] InternetMovieDatabase, accessed 23 August 2011 but after Bolt's success with ''The Flowering Cherry'', he reworked it for the stage. It was first performed in London opening at the [[Gielgud Theatre|Globe Theatre]] (now Gielgud Theatre) on 1 July 1960. It later found its way to Broadway, enjoying a critically and commercially successful run of over a year. It has had several revivals, and was subsequently made into a multi-[[Academy Award]]-winning [[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|1966 feature film]] and a [[A Man for All Seasons (1988 film)|1988 television movie]]. The plot is based on the historical events leading up to the execution of [[Sir Thomas More]], the 16th-century [[Lord Chancellor|Chancellor of England]], who refused to endorse King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s wish to divorce his wife [[Catherine of Aragon]], who did not bear him a son, so that he could marry [[Anne Boleyn]], the sister of his former mistress. The play portrays More as a man of principle, envied by rivals such as [[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] and loved by the common people and by his family. == Title == The title reflects 20th century agnostic playwright [[Robert Bolt]]’s portrayal of More as the ultimate man of [[conscience]]. As one who remains true to himself and his beliefs while adapting to all circumstances and times, despite external pressure or influence, More represents "a man for all seasons." Bolt borrowed the title from [[Robert Whittington]], a contemporary of More, who in 1520 wrote of him: ::"More is a man of an angel's wit and singular learning. I know not his fellow. For where is the man of that gentleness, lowliness and affability? And, as time requireth, a man of marvelous mirth and pastimes, and sometime of as sad gravity. A man for all seasons."{{cite web|url=http://www.catholiceducation.org/en/controversy/politics-and-the-church/a-man-for-all-seasons-an-historian-s-demur.html|title=A Man for all Seasons: an Historian's Demur |publisher=Catholiceducation.org |date=4 December 1977 |accessdate=28 December 2016}} == Themes == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}} [[File: Hans Holbein, the Younger - Sir Thomas More - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|Sir [[Thomas More]], one of the most famous early Lord Chancellors, served and was executed under King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]].]] ''A Man for All Seasons'' struggles with ideas of identity and conscience. More argues repeatedly that a person is defined by his [[conscience]]. His own position is depicted as almost indefensible; the [[Pope Clement VII|Pope]] is described as a "bad" and corrupt individual, forced by the [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Charles V]] to act according to his will. But as More says to Norfolk, "What matters is not that it's true, but that I believe it; or no, not that I '''believe''' it, but that '''I''' believe it." More fears that if he breaks with his conscience, he will be damned to hell, while his associates and friends are more concerned with holding onto their own temporal power. At another key point of the play, More testifies before an inquiry committee and Norfolk attempts to persuade him to sign the [[Act Respecting the Oath to the Succession|Succession to the Crown Act 1534]] (pp. 78, Heinemann edition): Norfolk: : Oh, confound all this. ... I'm not a scholar, as Master Cromwell never tires of pointing out, and frankly, I don't know whether the marriage was lawful or not. But damn it, Thomas, look at those names. ... You know those men! Can't you do what I did, and come with us, for fellowship? More: : And when we stand before God, and you are sent to Paradise for doing according to your conscience, and I am damned for not doing according to mine, will you come with me, for fellowship? More's persecution is made to seem even more unjust by the inclusion of [[Eustace Chapuys]], the long-time Imperial ambassador to England, in the story. Chapuys recognizes More as a stout man of the church, and in Act II, after More's resignation from the Chancellorship, he informs More of a planned rebellion along the Scottish border, expecting More to be sympathetic. Instead, More informs Norfolk of the plot, showing him to be patriotic and loyal to the King. This, along with More's refusal to speak out against the King, shows him to be a loyal subject, and thus Cromwell appears to prosecute him out of personal spite and because he disagrees with the King's divorce. Bolt also establishes an anti-authoritarian theme which recurs throughout his works. All people in positions of power – King Henry, Cromwell, Wolsey, Cranmer, Chapuys, even Norfolk – are depicted as being either corrupt, evil, or at best expedient and power-hungry. Bolt's later plays and film screenplays also delve into this theme. The theme of corruption is also illustrated, in Rich's rise to power, the Common Man being drawn into the events of the storyline, and in the (deliberately) anachronistic portrayal of Henry as a younger, athletic man (in 1530 he would have been almost forty and already putting on weight). Although it is the law that eventually forces More's execution, the play also makes several powerful statements in support of the rule of law. At one point More's future son-in-law, Roper, urges him to arrest Richard Rich, whose perjury will eventually lead to More's execution. More answers that Rich has broken no law, "And go he should if he were the Devil himself until he broke the law!" Roper is appalled at the idea of granting the Devil the benefit of law, but More is adamant. :"What would you do? Cut a great road through the law to get after the Devil? ... And when the last law was down, and the Devil turned round on you – where would you hide, Roper, the laws all being flat? This country is planted thick with laws from coast to coast, Man's laws, not God's, and if you cut them down – and you're just the man to do it – do you really think you could stand upright in the winds that would blow then? Yes, I give the Devil benefit of law, for my own safety's sake!" The character of the Common Man serves as a narrator and framing device. A [[Brecht]]ian character, he plays various small parts – More's servant, a publican, a boatman, More's jailer, jury foreman and executioner—who appear throughout the play, both taking part in and commenting on the action. Several sequences involving this character break the [[fourth wall]]—most notably, a sequence where the Common Man attempts to exit the stage and is addressed by Cromwell, who identifies him as a jury foreman. (Indeed, the "jury" consists of sticks or poles with the hats of the Common Man's various characters put on top.) The place of the Common Man in history is emphasized when he says in his opening speech, "the sixteenth century was the century of the Common Man-like all the other centuries." Bolt created the Common Man for two main reasons: to illustrate the place and influence of the average person in history, even though they are usually overlooked, and to try to prevent the audience from sympathising with the more titled characters such as More, realising that the audience is more closely related to him—a classic case of Brechtian [[alienation effect|alienation]]. The character's role in the story has been interpreted in many different ways by different critics, from being a positive to a negative character. Bolt's own view (expressed in the preface to the play) was that he was intended to draw the audience into the play and that "common" denoted "that which is common to us all." {{Cite book|title=A Man for All seasons|last=Bolt|first=Robert|publisher=Heinemann|year=1963|isbn=|editor-last=Wood|editor-first=E.R.|edition=The Hereford Plays|location=London|pages=xviii|orig-year=1960}} Several of Bolt's subsequent works feature similar characters (e.g. ''The Thwarting of Baron Bolligrew,'' ''[[State of Revolution]]''). == Endings == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}} Two different endings were written by Bolt. The original ending, performed during the show's preliminary run in England, had Cromwell and Chapuys confront each other after More's execution and then exit the stage, hand in hand, chuckling with "the self-mocking, self-indulgent, rather rueful laughter of the men who know what the world is and how to be comfortable in it". This particular ending is exemplary of Bolt's notion of "riding with the current", as is demonstrated by "men who know what the world is and how to be comfortable in it", forsaking one's conscience in exchange of a life of "convenience". For the show's London production – and most, if not all, subsequent runs of the show – the Common Man sheds his executioner's garb and addresses the audience one final time: :"... It isn't difficult to keep alive, friends – just don't make trouble – or if you must make trouble, make the sort of trouble that's expected... If we should bump into one another, recognize me." The [[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|film version]] of the play ends with More's execution, followed by a narrator reading off the fates of the various characters involved (originally, this was dialogue spoken by the Common Man prior to the Tower of London Inquiry). ==Stage productions== [[Paul Scofield]], who played the leading role in the West End premiere, reprised it on Broadway in 1961, winning a [[Tony Award]]. Both productions were directed by [[Noel Willman]]. The original West End cast, playing at the [[Gielgud Theatre|Globe Theatre]] (now Gielgud Theatre), included: *The Common Man – [[Leo McKern]] *[[Thomas More|Sir Thomas More]] – [[Paul Scofield]] *[[Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich|Richard Rich]] – John Brown *[[Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk|Duke of Norfolk]] – [[Alexander Gauge]] *[[Alice, Lady More|Alice More]] – Wynne Clark *[[Margaret Roper|Margaret]] – [[Pat Keen]] *[[Thomas Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]] – [[Willoughby Goddard]] *[[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] – [[Andrew Keir]] *[[Eustace Chapuys|Chapuys]] – Geoffrey Dunn *Attendant – Brian Harrison *[[William Roper (biographer)|Will Roper]] – [[John Carson (actor)|John Carson]] *[[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] – [[Richard Leech]] *Woman – Beryl Andrews *[[Thomas Cranmer|Archbishop Cranmer]] – William Roderick In London, ''Man'' ran simultaneously to another of Bolt's plays, ''[[The Tiger and the Horse]]''. Both plays were major hits, although ''Horse'' was the more successful of the two. British critical reaction was largely positive, albeit reservedly so; few reviews at the time regarded the play as a classic. The show ran for 320 performances. In the USA, the play was first performed on Broadway on 22 November 1961, at the [[ANTA Playhouse]] '''Original Broadway cast''' *The Common Man – [[George Rose (actor)|George Rose]] *[[Thomas More|Sir Thomas More]] – [[Paul Scofield]] *[[Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk|The Duke of Norfolk]] – [[Albert Dekker]] *[[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] – [[Leo McKern]] (later [[Thomas Gomez]]) *[[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]] – [[Keith Baxter (actor)|Keith Baxter]] *[[Margaret Roper|Margaret More]] – Olga Bellin *[[William Roper (biographer)|William Roper]] – Peter Brandon *Catherine Anger – Sarah Burton *Attendant – John Colenback *[[Thomas Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]] – Jack Creley *[[Alice, Lady More|Alice More]]- [[Carol Goodner]] *[[Thomas Cranmer]] – Lester Rawlins *[[Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich|Richard Rich]] – [[William Redfield (actor)|William Redfield]] *[[Eustace Chapuys|Signor Chapuys]] – [[David J. Stewart]] The Broadway production was a huge hit, running for 620 performances. While the play had drawn mixed critical reviews in London, it was almost unanimously praised by the New York critics, who showered it with plaudits and awards. Leo McKern played the Common Man in the West End version of the show, but was shifted to the role of Cromwell for the Broadway production – a role he later reprised in the film. While playing Cromwell, he appeared with one brown and one blue eye (McKern of course had lost an eye in an accident and wore a glass one) to accentuate his character's evil nature. [[Charlton Heston]] played More in several versions of the play-off-Broadway in the 1970s and 1980s, eventually playing it on the West End. The play was a success and the West End production was taken to Aberdeen, Scotland, for a week where it was staged at His Majesty's Theatre. Heston considered it among his favourite roles. He also produced, directed, and starred in a film version of it (see below). The production gained a sort of notoriety when Dustin Hoffman spread the story that Heston, who was bald, was so vain that he wore a wig over his hairpiece, rather than let the public view his actual bald pate. Another famous graduate of the play is [[Ian McKellen]], whose first theatrical role was as Will Roper in a revival production in the late 1960s. He would go on to play More in a later run of the show. [[Faye Dunaway]] also made her stage debut as a replacement Margaret in the original Broadway run. An acclaimed Canadian production starring [[William Hutt (actor)|William Hutt]] and directed by [[Walter Learning]] was presented at the [[Vancouver Playhouse (theatre venue)|Vancouver Playhouse]] and the [[Stratford Festival]] in 1986. At Stratford the production was paired with a production of Shakespeare's ''Henry VIII'', with both plays sharing many actors, and showing two perspectives on historical events. The play was staged in London's West End at the [[Haymarket Theatre|Theatre Royal, Haymarket]] starring [[Martin Shaw]] and produced by [[Bill Kenwright]]. It closed on 1 April 2006. A Broadway revival of the show, produced by the [[Roundabout Theatre Company]], starring [[Frank Langella]] as More and directed by [[Doug Hughes]], played at the [[American Airlines Theatre]] through December 2008. In this production, the character of The Common Man was deleted by the director (as Bolt had done when adapting his play for the first film version).{{cite web|last=Cox |first=Gordon |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117986277.html?categoryid=15&cs=1&nid=2563 |title=Frank Langella to be 'Man' on B'way – Entertainment News, Legit News, Media – Variety |publisher=Variety.com |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=23 August 2011}} {{anchor|HK-antiCommunist01a}}In 2008, Thomas More was also portrayed on stage in [[Hong Kong]] as an [[allegorical]] symbol of the [[Pro-democracy camp in Hong Kong|Pan-democracy camp]] resisting [[Chinese Communism]] when Hardy Tsoi, after translating ''A Man for All Seasons'', mainly into [[Cantonese]], but also with some parts in [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Latin]], and English, produced it as a play within a play. Similarities were noted between More and contemporary pro-democracy politicians in Hong Kong such as [[Martin Lee]] and [[Szeto Wah]], with the [[Holy See|Vatican]] being seen as representing [[British Hong Kong|British colonialism]] while Henry VIII and his regime were seen as representing [[China|Communist China]] "suppressing democracy and freedom" in Hong Kong.{{cite book |author= Chen, Chapman |title= "Postcolonial Hong Kong Drama Translation" in "Beyond Borders: Translations Moving Languages, Literatures and Cultures" |url= https://books.google.ie/books?id=S4-MqkBKvg4C&pg=PA48&dq=%22thomas+More%22+China&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uh6uVKyTH6La7gbmsICIDw&ved=0CCcQuwUwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22thomas%20More%22%20China&f=false |series= [https://www.google.ie/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=bibliogroup:%22Trans%C3%9CD.+Arbeiten+zur+Theorie+und+Praxis+des+%C3%9Cbersetzens+und+Dolmetschens%22&source=gbs_metadata_r&cad=4 Volume 39 of TransÜD. Arbeiten zur Theorie und Praxis des Übersetzens und Dolmetschens] |editor= Pekka Kujamäki |accessdate= January 8, 2015 |year= 2011 |pages=47–54 |publisher= [[:de:Frank & Timme|Frank & Timme GmbH]], [[Berlin]] |isbn= 9783865963567 }} According to Chapman Chen, Hardy Tsoi's version of the play is one of a number of Hong Kong works that suggest that mainstream [[Postcolonial theory|postcolonial theories]] which invariably portray European [[colonialism]] as oppressive need to be "modified or balanced" to reflect the different experience of places like Hong Kong. ==Film and TV movies== The play was [[A Man for All Seasons (1964 film)|adapted for Australian television in 1964]]. ===1966 film=== {{main article|A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)}} [[Paul Scofield]], who played the leading role in the West End and Broadway stage premieres, played More again in the first of two film versions (1966), winning an [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Oscar]] in the process. The film also stars [[Robert Shaw (British actor)|Robert Shaw]] as Henry VIII, [[Orson Welles]] as [[Thomas Wolsey|Wolsey]], [[Corin Redgrave]] as Will Roper, [[Nigel Davenport]] as Norfolk, a young [[John Hurt]] as [[Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich|Richard Rich]], and an older [[Wendy Hiller]] as Lady Alice, More's second wife. It was directed by [[Fred Zinnemann]]. In addition to the [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor Oscar]] won by Scofield, the film won [[Academy Awards]] for screenplay, [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|cinematography]], costume design, [[Academy Award for Directing|Best Director]], and [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]. ===1988 film=== {{main article|A Man for All Seasons (1988 film)}} The 1988 version starred [[Charlton Heston]] (who also directed it) as More, [[Vanessa Redgrave]] (who appeared briefly and mutely in the 1966 version as [[Anne Boleyn]]) as More's wife, and Sir [[John Gielgud]] as Cardinal Wolsey. By coincidence, Gielgud's name now graces the former [[Gielgud Theatre|Globe Theatre]], where the original play premiered in 1960. ==Radio productions== The play was produced, with the following cast, as the [[Saturday Night Theatre]] on [[BBC Radio 4]] on 28 February 1959: *[[Sir Thomas More]] — [[John Franklyn-Robbins]] *Master [[Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich|Richard Rich]] — [[Michael Graham Cox|Michael Cox]] *Master [[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] — David Mahlowe *[[Thomas Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]] — Ralph Hallett *[[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]] — [[David Scase]] *[[Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk|Duke of Norfolk]] — David Sumner *Dame [[Alice, Lady More|Alice More]] — Cynthia Grenville *Mistress [[Margaret Roper|Margaret (Meg) More]] — Marah Stohl *[[Thomas Cranmer|Archbishop Thomas Cranmer]] — [[Stephen MacDonald]] *The Bishop of Bath — [[Christopher Benjamin]] *The Bishop of Durham — [[Bernard Kay]] The play was produced, with the following cast, as the [[Saturday Play]] on [[BBC Radio 4]] on 7 October 2006, as part of its Betrayal season: *[[Sir Thomas More]] — [[Charles Dance]] *Master [[Richard Rich, 1st Baron Rich|Richard Rich]] — [[Julian Rhind Tutt]] *Master [[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] — [[Kenneth Cranham]] *[[Thomas Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]] — [[Timothy Bateson]] *[[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]] — [[Brian Cox (actor)|Brian Cox]] *[[Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk|Duke of Norfolk]] — [[Nicholas le Prevost]] *Master [[William Roper (biographer)|William Roper]] — [[Martin Freeman]] *[[Alice, Lady More|Alice More]] — [[Kika Markham]] *Mistress [[Margaret Roper|Margaret (Meg) More]] — [[Romola Garai]] *Boatman/Steward (aka Matthew) /Jailer — Dan Chyutin *[[Thomas Cranmer|Archbishop Thomas Cranmer]]/Headsman — Peter Tate *Catherine of Aragon — [[Adjoa Andoh]] ==See also== * [[Trial movies]] *[[Cultural depictions of Henry VIII of England]] == References== {{Infobox company | name = AboveNet | fate = Acquired by [[Zayo Group]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1993}} | defunct = {{end date and age|2012|07|02}} | location = [[White Plains, New York]] | revenue = {{increase}} $472 million (2011) | net_income = {{increase}} $72 million (2011) | assets = {{increase}} $911 million (2011) | equity = {{increase}} $647 million (2011) | num_employees = 713 (2011) | footnotes = <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1043533/000114420412011778/v303647_10k.htm | title=AboveNet, Inc. 2011 Form 10-K Annual Report | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}}</ref> }}
'''AboveNet''' was a provider of high [[Bandwidth (computing)|bandwidth]] [[telecommunication circuit]]s primarily for large corporate enterprises and communications carriers in 17 markets in the United States and four markets in Europe. Its private optical network delivered key network and IP services and was used in financial and legal services, media, health care, retail, and government.
The company was formerly named Metromedia Fiber Network and changed its name to AboveNet in 2003 after emerging from [[bankruptcy]].
Before its bankruptcy in 2002, the company was financially backed by [[John Kluge]] and [[Verizon]].
In 2012, the company was acquired by [[Zayo Group]] for $2.2 billion in cash.
==History== The company was founded in 1993 as National Fiber Network. It initially focused on providing [[dark fiber]] to communications carrier customers in the U.S. and Europe.
In 1997, the company changed its name to Metromedia Fiber Network.
In 1999, Metromedia acquired Abovenet Communications, including its subsidiary [[PAIX]], an operator of Internet [[peering]] exchanges.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB930142020565956674 | title=Metromedia Fiber Network Plans To Buy AboveNet for $1.76 Billion | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=June 24, 1999}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/24/business/company-news-metromedia-to-buy-abovenet-for-1.55-billion.html | title=Metromedia to Buy Abovenet for $1.55 Billion | agency=[[Reuters]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=June 24, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/1999/06/23/deals/metromedia/ | title=Metromedia buys AboveNet | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=June 24, 1999}}</ref> Abovenet Communications had become a [[public company]] via an [[initial public offering]] in December 1998 and soared 32% in one day in March 1999 during the [[dot-com bubble]] after announcing a [[stock split]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/31/business/abovenet-to-split-stock.html | title=Abovenet to Split Stock | agency=[[Dow Jones & Company]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=March 31, 1999}}</ref>
In 2000, the company acquired M.I.B.H., a networking consultancy operated by [[Paul Vixie]], for $51 million in cash and stock.
Also in 2000, [[Verizon]] invested $970 million in [[convertible bond]]s and $715.4 million in common stock of the company.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/31/business/technology-verizon-may-write-down-big-fiber-optic-investment.html | title=Verizon May Write Down Big Fiber Optic Investment | first=Simon | last=Romero | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 21, 2001}}</ref>
In 2001, the company acquired SiteSmith, a provider of managed web-hosting services, for $1.36 billion in stock.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/10/10/deals/metromedia/ | title=Metromedia buys SiteSmith | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=October 10, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/oct/11/business/fi-34755 | title=Metromedia Fiber Network Plans Acquisition of SiteSmith | agency=[[Reuters]] | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=October 11, 2000}}</ref>
In May 2002, the company filed [[bankruptcy]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/21/business/technology-metromedia-fiber-files-for-bankruptcy.html | title=Metromedia Fiber Files for Bankruptcy | first=Simon | last=Romero | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 21, 2000}}</ref>
In September 2003, the company emerged from bankruptcy and changed its name to Abovenet, with [[Craig McCaw]], Franklin Mutual Advisers, and [[John Kluge]] among its largest shareholders.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/09/business/technology-briefing-hardware-abovenet-emerges-from-bankruptcy.html | title=AboveNet Emerges From Bankruptcy | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 9, 2003}}</ref>
In October 2006, [[Digital Realty]] acquired the east coast [[data center]]s of the company for $40 million.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://investor.digitalrealty.com/investor-relations/news-and-events/news/news-details/2006/Digital-Realty-Trust-Inc-Acquires-Datacenters-in-New-York-City-and-Northern-Virginia-From-AboveNet/default.aspx | title=Digital Realty Trust, Inc. Acquires Datacenters in New York City and Northern Virginia From AboveNet | publisher=[[PR Newswire]] | date=October 2, 2006}}</ref>
In 2007, the company acquired fiber from [[AT&T]] and Verizon that the companies were selling to comply with antitrust law.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://news.thomasnet.com/companystory/abovenet-acquires-metro-fiber-from-at-and-t-and-verizon-515293 | title=AboveNet Acquires Metro Fiber from AT&T and Verizon | publisher=[[Thomas Register]] | date=April 11, 2007}}</ref>
On July 2, 2012, [[Zayo Group]] acquired the company for $2.2 billion in cash.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/denver/news/2012/07/02/zayo-group-closes-on-23b-buy-of.html | title=Zayo Group closes on $2.3B buy of AboveNet | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=July 2, 2012}}</ref>

300+ killed (pro-government claim){{cite web|url=http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13950502000712|title=Terrorists Lose 40 Tanks, 300 Fighters in Aleppo|date=23 July 2016}} |casualties3= | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Syrian Civil War}}{{Campaignbox Battle of Aleppo}} }} The '''Aleppo offensive (June–July 2016)''' refers to a military operation launched on the northern outskirts of [[Aleppo]] in late June 2016, by the [[Syrian Army]]. The aim of the offensive was to cut the last rebel supply line into Aleppo city.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-06/26/c_135467722.htm|title=Syrian army unleashes broad offensive in Aleppo|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-4241-Syria-Army-bid-to-cut-off-Aleppo-unleashes-fierce-fighting#.V3WUhut96Uk|title=Syria: Army bid to cut off Aleppo unleashes fierce fighting|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630013917/http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-4241-Syria-Army-bid-to-cut-off-Aleppo-unleashes-fierce-fighting#.V3WUhut96Uk|archive-date=30 June 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==The offensive== ===Northern Army advances and capture of the Mallah Farms=== [[File:12alep.png|thumb|left|Map of the offensive]] The offensive on 25 June, was preceded by heavy Russian air-strikes.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/heavy-russian-airstrikes-aleppo/|title=Heavy Russian airstrikes on Aleppo amid preparations for huge ground offensive|first=Izat|last=Charkatli|date=25 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Heavy ground bombardment was also involved before the ground offensive was launched. The pro-government al-Watan newspaper said the amount of firepower used was "unprecedented," with local sources describing the fighting in the area as "World War III". Overall, heavy mortars, rocket launchers, airstrikes and tank fire were used.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1718716/syrian-government-forces-close-in-on-aleppo|title=Syrian Government Forces Close In On Aleppo|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} The Army attempted to advance in the northwestern part of the city, as well as in the Mallah farmlands to the north, near the Castello Road, the rebels' last supply route into Aleppo. Initially, the Army managed to capture several positions in the northwestern al-Zahra and al-Khalidiyah districts of Aleppo.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/tiger-forces-begin-long-awaited-northern-aleppo-offensive/|title=Tiger Forces begin long-awaited northern Aleppo offensive|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=25 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/detailed-report-aleppos-overnight-offensive/|title=A detailed report of Aleppo's overnight offensive|first=Ibra|last=Joudeh|date=25 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} By the next morning, over a 5-hour period, the Russian Air Force had conducted over 60 air-strikes against rebel positions.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/russians-launch-60-airstrikes-northern-aleppo/|title=Russians launches non-stop air campaign over northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=26 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} On 26 June, the military made advances into the Mallah Farms,{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/field-report-syrian-army-advances-northern-aleppo-amid-intensifying-battles/|title=Field Report: Syrian Army advances in northern Aleppo amid intensifying battles|first=Zen|last=Adra|date=26 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} and by 28 June, they had captured half of the farmlands,{{cite web|url=http://www.heart.co.uk/news/uk-world/syrian-government-forces-close-in-on-aleppo/#2FQX2A4IH9zqzwh3.97|title=Syrian Government Forces Close In On Aleppo|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629160241/http://www.heart.co.uk/news/uk-world/syrian-government-forces-close-in-on-aleppo/#2FQX2A4IH9zqzwh3.97|archive-date=29 June 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} including the Al-Asamat and Arab Salum areas.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-battle-update-syrian-army-fully-recaptures-eastern-parts-mallah-map/|title=Aleppo Battle Update: Syrian Army fully recaptures eastern parts of Mallah + [Map]|first=Zen|last=Adra|date=26 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} The advances brought the Castello Road within firing range of the military's artillery.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/syrian-troops-capture-important-area-near-the-city-of-aleppo/2016/06/28/1109d1fa-3d26-11e6-9e16-4cf01a41decb_story.html|title=US-backed Syrian rebels move toward IS-held town near Iraq|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Concurrently with the government's advances, the Russian Air Forces continued conducting heavy air-strikes, with just 30 strikes on the morning of 27 June, above the Handarat Mountains and Anadan Plains.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/russian-air-force-strikes-northern-aleppo-amid-syrian-army-advance/|title=Russian Air Force strikes northern Aleppo amid Syrian Army advance|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=27 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Still, despite the advances, the Army was unable to advance by nightfall{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/latest-field-update-northern-aleppo-map/|title=Latest field update from northern Aleppo: map|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=29 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} into the western and southern farms of Malaah, despite repeated attempts over the previous day.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/jihadists-hold-ground-syrian-army-attempts-advance-northern-aleppo/|title=Jihadists hold their ground as the Syrian Army attempts to advance in northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=28 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/breaking-syrian-armed-forces-continue-northern-aleppo-offensive/|title=Breaking: Syrian Armed Forces continue northern Aleppo offensive|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=27 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} On 28 June, the military advanced in al-Khalidiyah towards the industrial zone of al-Layramoun and Bani Zeid. On 29 June, an initial rebel counter-attack at Mallah was repelled.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/field-report-jihadi-rebels-attack-northern-aleppo-repelled/|title=Field Report: Jihadi rebels attack on northern Aleppo repelled|first=Zen|last=Adra|date=29 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Still, later in the day, the rebels used two suicide car bombers, forcing the military to withdraw from all areas they had captured at Mallah.{{cite web|url=https://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2016/Jun-30/359897-at-least-70-killed-in-north-of-syrias-aleppo-activists.ashx|title=At least 70 killed in north of Syria's Aleppo: activists|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-withdraws-al-malaah-farms-northern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Army withdraws from Al-Malaah Farms in northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=29 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} It was initially reported government forces had retreated to regroup for a new assault. However, subsequently it was stated it was a tactical retreat so to lure rebel forces into a trap and inflict maximum casualties.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-walk-directly-tiger-forces-trap-northern-aleppo/|title=Islamist rebels walk directly into Tiger Forces trap in northern Aleppo|first=Chris|last=Tomson|date=30 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Following this, on 30 June, government forces managed to retake all positions they had lost the previous day.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-recaptures-lost-points-al-malaah-farms-northern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Army recaptures all lost points at Al-Malaah Farms in northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=30 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/892691310839208?hc_location=ufi|title=15 airstrikes target areas of Aleppo... - Syrian Observatory for Human Rights - Facebook|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/photos/a.150495128392167.28686.121855461256134/893339400774399/?type=3&theater|title=the regime forces advance again north... - Syrian Observatory for Human Rights - Facebook|publisher=|accessdate=2 July 2016}} Between 2 and 3 July, the Army advanced in the southern farms of Mallah, coming within two kilometers of cutting the Castelo Road.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2016/Jul-03/360301-syria-government-rebels-battle-for-key-farms-north-of-aleppo-activists.ashx|title=Syria government, rebels battle for key farms north of Aleppo: activists|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-advances-key-jihadist-area-northern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Armed Forces advance at key jihadist area in northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=2 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}} On 3 July, a Russian cruise missile reportedly destroyed a rebel [[BGM-71 TOW|TOW]] storage base in western Aleppo.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/russian-cruise-missile-obliterates-rebel-tow-storage-base-western-aleppo/|title=Russian cruise missile obliterates rebel TOW storage base in western Aleppo|first=Chris|last=Tomson|date=3 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}} The same day, the military captured the Shbeib factory and several nearby blocks in the al-Layramoun district of Aleppo. The following day, a rebel counter-attack, which included a suicide bomber, was repelled.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/videos-syrian-army-advances-urban-warfare-aleppo-city/|title=VIDEOS: Syrian Army advances during urban warfare in Aleppo city|first=Chris|last=Tomson|date=3 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/aleppo-battle-update-syrian-army-foils-rebels-attack-northern-aleppo/|title=Aleppo Battle Update: Syrian Army foils rebel attack in northern Aleppo|first=Zen|last=Adra|date=4 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}} At the same time, the Army captured more positions in the southern part of Mallah, bringing 65–75 percent of the farms area under its control. A new rebel counter-attack in Mallah was also repelled.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-advances-northern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Army advances in northern Aleppo|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=4 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-foils-massive-jihadist-counter-offensive-northern-aleppo/|title=Syrian Army foils massive jihadist counter-offensive in northern Aleppo|first=Izat|last=Charkatli|date=5 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}} After midnight on 7 July, amid heavy airstrikes, pro-government forces captured the southern part of Mallah and came within one kilometer of the Castello Road.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-aleppo-idUSKCN0ZN0U2|title=Syrian army fire cuts only road into rebel-held Aleppo: rebels|work=Reuters|date=7 July 2016}} They captured a mosque complex and a hill which overlook the Castello Road,{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3678994/Fierce-fighting-key-Aleppo-road-despite-Syria-truce.html|title=Fierce fighting for key Aleppo road despite Syria truce|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-36735196|title=Syria conflict: Army fire 'cuts key Aleppo road' - BBC News|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} thus enabling them to bring the road under artillery fire-control.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/breaking-aleppo-rebels-trapped-as-syrian-army-cuts-off-main-supply-route/|title=Aleppo rebels trapped as Syrian Army cuts off main supply route. Map Update|first=Zen|last=Adra|date=7 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} This effectively cut off the only supply route to the rebel-held part of Aleppo. The rebels sent in reinforcements in an attempt to retake the area; however, an assault against the hill was repelled. On 8 July, the Kurdish [[People's Protection Units|YPG]] launched an assault of their own from the Kurdish-held northern part of Aleppo city against the rebel-held Youth Housing Complex, located alongside the Castello Road.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/kurds-launch-surprise-offensive-aleppo-city/|title=Kurds launch surprise offensive in Aleppo city, rebels in dire state|first=Izat|last=Charkatli|date=8 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} Meanwhile, the military made more advances in the Mallah area,{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/syriahroe/posts/897481247026881|title=Syrian Observatory for Human Rights|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} coming within 250 meters of the Castello Road.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-armed-forces-continue-aleppo-encirclement/|title=Syrian Armed Forces continue Aleppo encirclement|first=Leith|last=Fadel|date=8 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} Elsewhere in Aleppo city, rebel shelling of government-held areas killed 23–34 civilians and wounded 140–200.{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1429083/civilians-killed-north-syria-monitor|title=Over 60 civilians killed in north Syria: monitor|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2016}} ===Rebel counter-attacks repelled, southern Army advances=== On 9 July, the rebels launched a counter-attack against government positions near the Castello Road, which was led by two suicide car-bombers.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/rocket-attacks-kill-30-syrias-aleppo-40455571|title=Syria's Military Extends Cease-Fire but No Letup in Fighting|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=12 July 2016}} Initially, the rebels recaptured some areas near the Castello … Russians Shelling Aleppo’s Neighborhood - Qasion News Agency|publisher=|accessdate=12 July 2016}} Later that night, heavy Russian air-strikes hit rebel forces along the road to the Mallah Farms, as
