'''Robert Morton Nance''' (1873–1959) was a leading authority on the [[Cornish language]], nautical archaeologist, and joint founder of the [[Federation of Old Cornwall Societies|Old Cornwall Society]].
Nance was born in [[Cardiff]] to Cornish parents. He wrote many books and pamphlets on the [[Cornish language]], including a Cornish [[dictionary]], which is a standard work, and edited magazines and pamphlets about [[Cornwall]], including ''Old Cornwall'', the journal of the [[Federation of Old Cornwall Societies]]. Nance was also a [[nautical archaeology|nautical archaeologist]] of distinction and was an originator of the [[Society for Nautical Research]]. His insight and learning were displayed in his book ''Sailing-ship Models'' which appeared in 1924. He studied art in Britain and [[France]] and was both a painter and a skilled craftsman.
==Chronology of his life== {{prose|date=August 2017}} *1873: He was born in Cardiff *1898: He wrote "The Merry Ballad of the Cornish Pasty".<ref name="hall">Hall, Stephen (2001) ''The Cornish Pasty''. Nettlecombe: Agre Books {{ISBN|0-9538000-4-0}}</ref> *1906: He moved from [[Wales]] and settled at [[Nancledra]] near [[St Ives, Cornwall]]. *1911: He jointly founded the [[Society for Nautical Research]]. *1920: Together with [[Henry Jenner]], he founded the first [[Federation of Old Cornwall Societies|Old Cornwall Society]] at [[St Ives, Cornwall|St Ives]]. *1924: The Federation of Old Cornwall Societies was established. *1925: The Federation established the periodical ''Old Cornwall''. *1928: He jointly founded the [[Gorsedh Kernow]], which was inaugurated at [[Boscawen-Un]], where he took the [[bardic name]] ''Mordon'' ('[[wind wave|Sea Wave]]'). *1929: He published ''Cornish for All'' using the [[Unified Cornish]] spelling system. *1951 - 1955: He was President of the [[Royal Institution of Cornwall]] for 1951 - 1955.<ref>Brian Murdoch, "Nance, Robert Morton (1873-1959)", [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/63389 accessed 15 Nov 2007]</ref> *1959: He died and was buried at St Senara's churchyard, [[Zennor]]<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/85393255 Robert Morton Nance (1873-1959)]; Find a Grave</ref>
==Selected list of works== *1912: {{cite book|last1=[[E. E. Speight|Speight]]|first1=E E|last2=Nance|first2=R Morton|title=Britain's Sea Story|date=1912-01-01|publisher=Henry Frowde }} {{ASIN|B000LQ60UM| country=uk}} *1923: ''A Glossary of Celtic Words in Cornish Dialect''. Falmouth: Royal Cornwall Polytechnic Society *1924: ''Sailing-ship Models: a selection from European and American collections with introductory text''. London: Halton and Truscott Smith (photographs) **---do.---2nd rev. ed. London; New York: Halton, 1949 **''Classic Sailing-ship Models in Photographs.'' Reprinted [[Dover Publications]], Mineola, NY, 2000 {{ISBN|0-486-41249-0}} *1925- : ''Old Cornwall'', as editor and contributor. **Articles in ''Old Cornwall'', including "The Cornish Language in the Seventeenth Century", in: ''Old Cornwall''; vol. VI, no. 1. *1955: ''Cornish-English Dictionary''. Federation of Old Cornwall Societies {{ISBN|0-902660-05-5}} *1956: ''The Cledry Plays: drolls of Old Cornwall for village acting and home reading''. Federation of Old Cornwall Societies B0000CJH1W {{Clarify|date=December 2009}} *1961: ''Cornish for All'': a guide to Unified Cornish. Federation of Old Cornwall Societies. B0000CKWG1 {{clarify|date=October 2010}} *[n.d.]: ''A Guide to Cornish Place-names; with a list of the words contained in them''. Federation of Old Cornwall Societies. (Three editions, before 1971.)

Gen.]] | name = Ronald dela Rosa | image = Ronald dela Rosa 073116 (cropped).jpg | imagesize = | caption = | office = [[Bureau of Corrections (Philippines)|Director-General of the Bureau of Corrections]] | president = [[Rodrigo Duterte]] | term_start = April 30, 2018 | term_end = October 12, 2018 | predecessor = Rey Raagas (OIC) | successor = [[Nicanor Faeldon]] | office2 = [[Philippine National Police Chief|Chief]] of the [[Philippine National Police]] | president2 = [[Rodrigo Duterte]] | term_start2 = July 1, 2016 | term_end2 = April 19, 2018 | predecessor2 = Ricardo Marquez | successor2 = [[Oscar Albayalde]] | birth_name = Ronald Marapon dela Rosa | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1962|1|21}} | birth_place = Barangay Bato, [[Santa Cruz, Davao del Sur|Santa Cruz]], [[Davao del Sur]], Philippines[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:3Q9M-CSWC-PS1K?mode=g Ronald dela Rosa Birth Certificate]Tejano, I. (2016, May 18). [http://www.sunstar.com.ph/davao/local-news/2016/05/19/duterte-picks-dela-rosa-next-pnp-chief-474400 Duterte picks Dela Rosa as next PNP chief], ''Sun Star Davao'' | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | party = | spouse = {{marriage|Nancy Comandante|1989}} | relations = | children = 3 | residence = | alma_mater = [[Mindanao State University]]
[[Philippine Military Academy]] (Class of 1986)
[[University of Southeastern Philippines]] | occupation = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | module = {{Infobox police officer | other_names = Bato, Duroy (PMA) |child=yes |allegiance= {{flag|Philippines}} | serviceyears = 1986{{spaced ndash}}2018 | department = [[Philippine Constabulary]] (former)
[[Philippine National Police]] |rank=*Lieutenant (1986-2012) *Davao Police Chief (2012-2013) *[[File:PNP_GEN_Svc.svg|12px]] [[Director General (Philippine National Police)|Director General]] (2016-2018) }} }} '''Ronald Marapon dela Rosa''' (born January 21, 1962), also known as '''Bato dela Rosa''' or simply '''Bato''' ({{literal translation| Rock}}), is a retired [[Filipinos|Filipino]] police officer who serves as the Director General of the [[Bureau of Corrections (Philippines)|Director of the Bureau of Corrections]] from April 30, 2018 until October 12, 2018. He served as [[Philippine National Police Chief]] from July 1, 2016 to April 19, 2018.De Jesus, Julliane Love [http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/793636/its-official-dela-rosa-is-new-pnp-chief It’s official: Dela Rosa is new PNP chief], ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'', July 1, 2016 ==Early life and education== Dela Rosa was born on January 21, 1962 at [[Barangay]] Bato, [[Santa Cruz, Davao del Sur|Santa Cruz]], [[Davao del Sur]], to Teodoro Diamaton dela Rosa, Sr. and Anesia Cruspero Marapon. His family was "dirt poor" as his father earned little money working as a [[Motorized tricycle (Philippines)|tricycle]] driver.{{cite news|last1=De Jesus|first1=Julliane Love|title=What made ‘Bato’ cry|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/795254/what-made-bato-cry|accessdate=1 February 2017|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=July 10, 2016}} The young Dela Rosa worked as a [[fish market]] [[Porter (carrier)|porter]] and [[bus conductor]]. He also did his classmates' homework in exchange for lunch. He used to walk 8 kilometers daily from school to home.{{cite news|last1=Hontiveros|first1=Pia|title=The 'Bato' we don't know|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/videos/2016/06/08/The-Bato-we-dont-know.html|accessdate=1 February 2017|agency=''[[CNN Philippines]]''|date=June 9, 2016}} Dela Rosa was educated at Bato Elementary School and Sta. Cruz National High School before attending [[Mindanao State University]] (MSU) to study for a Bachelor of Science degree in [[public administration]].{{cite web|title=Dela Rosa Assumes Command as 21st Chief PNP|url=http://www.pnp.gov.ph/national-headquarters/directorate-for-information-and-communication-technology-management/17-news/latest-news/354-dela-rosa-assumes-command-as-21st-chief-pnp|publisher=''Philippine National Police''|accessdate=7 February 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Umel|first1=Richel|title=Dela Rosa speaks before grads in Marawi|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cagayan-de-oro/feature/2017/01/26/dela-rosa-speaks-grads-marawi-522343|accessdate=4 April 2017|publisher=SunStar Philippines|date=January 26, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Alawi|first1=Rebekah|title=Gen. Dela Rosa’s MSU Visit as Commencement Speaker: A Nostalgic Homecoming to What Once his Field of Dreams|url=http://www.msumain.edu.ph/details.php/university-news/gen-dela-rosa-s-msu-visit-as-commencement-speaker-first-semester-ay-2016-2017|accessdate=4 April 2017|publisher=Mindanao State University|date=January 2017}} In 1982, he left MSU to join the [[Philippine Military Academy]] (PMA) and graduated in 1986 as part of PMA ''Sinagtala'' class.{{cite web|last1=Dalizon|first1=Alfred P.|title=More on PMA Class 1986.|url=http://www.journal.com.ph/editorial/opinion/more-on-pma-class-1986|website=Journal Online|accessdate=23 July 2016}} He then earned a [[Masters of Public Administration]] degree in 1998 and a [[Ph.D.]] in development administration in 2006 from the [[University of Southeastern Philippines]] in [[Davao City]].University of Southeastern Philippines - [http://www.usep.edu.ph/cgb/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2016/07/delarosa-congratulatory-tarp.jpg ''Ronald dela Rosa Congratulatory Tarp''] Dela Rosa completed a [[Scout Ranger Regiment|Scout Ranger]] Orientation Course, Police Intelligence Officer Advance Course, Police Officers’ Comptrollership Course, and the Police Safety Officer Course. He also attended training courses of the [[FBI Academy]] and [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] [[Ranger School]] in the United States, and [[Sky marshal|Air Marshal]] Instructors Course by the [[Australian Federal Police]]. Dela Rosa was nicknamed "Bato" during his first assignment in Davao, when his upperclassmen likened his body to a rock.{{refn|''Bato'' is the [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] and [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] word for "rock" or "stone".{{cite book|last1=Nigg|first1=Charles|title=A Tagalog English and English Tagalog dictionary|date=1904|publisher=Imprenta de Fajardo y Compañía|location=Manila|page=12|url=https://archive.org/stream/atagalogenglish00nigggoog#page/n6/mode/2up|accessdate=24 May 2017}}{{cite book|last1=Rafferty|first1=Patrick|title=Visayan-English dictionary|date=1928|publisher=University of Michigan Library|location=Ann Arbor, Michigan|page=17|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/p/philamer/ack6070.0001.001/21?page=root;rgn=full+text;size=100;view=image|accessdate=24 May 2017}}|group=n}} ==Police career== ===Early career, 1986–2012=== Dela Rosa joined the police force in 1986 as a [[Lieutenant]] of the now-defunct [[Philippine Constabulary]]{{refn|On January 29, 1991, the [[Philippine Constabulary]] was merged with the [[Integrated National Police]] to form the [[Philippine National Police]].|group=n}} in [[Davao City]]. In 1992, he was designated as [[Chief Inspector#Philippines|Chief Inspector]] and worked as one of the staff at Police Regional Office (PRO)-Davao. In 1997, he was designated as police provincial director of [[Compostela Valley|Compostela Valley province]]. In 1999, he was assigned to the office of the Police Director of the Philippine National Police (PNP) at [[Camp Crame]] in [[Quezon City]]. In 2001, he returned to PRO-Davao and continued his service as deputy chief of the Office of the Regional Personnel and Human Resource and Development Division (ORPHRDD) of [[Davao Region|Region XI]]. In 2003, he was promoted to [[Superintendent (police)#Philippines|Police Superintendent]] and was assigned to Camp Catitipan in Davao City. He was then transferred to the Directorate for Human Resources Doctrine and Development as head of training. In 2005, he was assigned to the Davao City Police Office (DCPO) as city personnel officer. After eight months, he was transferred back to PRO-Davao and was promoted as chief of the Regional Intelligence and Investigation Division (RIID). In 2007, he became the director of the Compostela Valley Provincial Police Office (CVPPO) as its police chief. In 2008, he was promoted to a rank of [[Police rank#Philippines|Senior Superintendent]]. In 2009, he was moved to [[Davao del Sur]] where he served as director of the Davao del Sur Provincial Police Office (DSPPO). In 2011, he became the chief of the Regional Logistics and Research Development Division (RL-RDD) in PRO-Davao. In 2012, he was assigned to Davao City as the new director of the Davao City Police Office. ===Davao City Police Chief, 2012–2013=== Dela Rosa served as the chief of the [[Davao City]] Police Office from January 2012 to October 2013 under Mayors [[Sara Duterte]] (in office: June 30, 2010 – June 30, 2013) and [[Rodrigo Duterte]] (in office: June 30, 2013 – June 30, 2016).{{cite news|url=http://interaksyon.com/article/127863/duterte-places-3-former-davao-police-chiefs-on-pnp-chief-shortlist|title=Duterte places 3 former Davao police chiefs on PNP Chief shortlist|publisher=[[Interaksyon]]|last=Mellejor|first=Lillian C.|date=May 17, 2016|accessdate=July 1, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/133519-ronald-dela-rosa-duterte-pnp-chief|title=Duterte's 'Bato': Who is Ronald dela Rosa?|publisher=''[[Rappler]]''|last=Cupin|first=Bea|date=May 19, 2016|accessdate=July 8, 2016}} In 2012, he led the crackdown on the [[Motor vehicle theft|carnapping]] syndicate allegedly masterminded by Ryan "Baktin" Yu.{{cite news|last1=Mellejor|first1=Ayan C.|last2=Ramos|first2=Marlon|title=14 stolen cars seized in Davao raid|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/294396/14-stolen-cars-seized-in-davao-raid|accessdate=31 January 2017|publisher=''Philippine Daily Inquirer''|date=October 23, 2012}} In July 2013, he headed the successful rescue of the kidnapped Filipino-Chinese businesswoman Sally Chua.{{cite news|last1=Cayabyab|first1=Marc Jayson|title=Trader kidnapped in QC rescued in Davao; 3 kidnappers killed|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/317060/news/regions/trader-kidnapped-in-qc-rescued-in-davao-3-kidnappers-killed|accessdate=31 January 2017|agency=''GMA News''|date=July 11, 2013}}{{cite news|title=How kidnapped businesswoman was rescued in Davao|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/nation/regions/07/12/13/how-kidnapped-businesswoman-was-rescued-davao|accessdate=31 January 2017|agency=''ABS-CBN News''|publisher=ANC News Now|date=July 12, 2013}} He also directed the implementation of ''Oplan Tokhang'' ([[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] portmanteau for ''tuktok'', "knock", and ''hangyo'', "persuade") a campaign against [[Illegal drug trade in the Philippines|illegal drugs]] where the police literally knock on the doors of suspected [[drug user]]s and [[Illegal drug trade|distributors]] and persuade them to cease their illegal activities;{{cite news|last1=Lacorte|first1=Germelina|title=Davao City’s anti-illegal drugs campaign to go national|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/788429/davao-citys-anti-illegal-drugs-campaign-to-go-national|accessdate=31 January 2017|publisher=''Philippine Daily Inquirer''|date=May 31, 2016}} and ''Oplan Pakgang'', ([[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] portmanteau for “''Pitulon ang Kabatan-onan sa Gang''”, “Disciplining Youths in Gangs”) where the police, through a series of lectures and discussions, discouraged Davao City’s youth from joining [[Gang|criminal gangs]] and other illegal activities.{{cite news|title=Oplan Pakgang gipahigayon sa Davao City|url=http://www.bomboradyo.com/am-stations/cdo/cdo-news/item/16638-oplan-pakgang-gipahigayon-sa-davao-city|accessdate=31 January 2017|agency=''Bombo Davao''|date=9 August 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Tejano|first1=Ivy C.|title=Oplan Pakgang shifts to Bunawan, Buhangin|publisher=''Sun.Star Davao''|date=8 August 2013}} ===Camp Crame, 2013–2016=== After serving as Davao City Police Chief, Dela Rosa was assigned to the national headquarters of the Philippine National Police in [[Camp Crame]] where he worked for the PNP Intelligence Group from October 2013 to December 2014.{{cite news|last1=Alvarez|first1=Kathrina Charmaine|title='Bato' Dela Rosa assumes command of PNP|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/571996/news/nation/bato-dela-rosa-assumes-command-of-pnp|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=''GMA News''|date=July 1, 2016}} In 2015, Dela Rosa became a member of the PNP Board of Inquiry which investigated the [[Mamasapano clash]]. The aforementioned incident claimed the lives of 44 [[Special Action Force]] commandos, 17 [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] members and five civilians while the cops were on a mission to arrest international terrorist [[Zulkifli Abdhir]], alias Marwan.{{cite news|last1=Diola|first1=Camille|title=LIST: Members of PNP board of inquiry on Mamasapano clash|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/02/06/1420857/list-members-pnp-board-inquiry-mamasapano-clash|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=''The Philippine Star''|date=February 6, 2015}}{{cite web|title=BOARD OF INQUIRY AWARDED FOR INVALUABLE SERVICE|url=http://pnp.gov.ph/portal/index.php/features11/plans-and-programs/75-news/2488-board-of-inquiry-awarded-for-invaluable-service|website=PNP.GOV.PH|publisher=PNP Public Information Office|accessdate=28 July 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Philippines News Agency|title=Board of Inquiry on Mamasapano to complete final report by Feb. 26|url=http://interaksyon.com/article/104787/board-of-inquiry-on-mamasapano-to-complete-final-report-by-feb--26|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=''InterAksyon.com''|date=February 10, 2015}} Dela Rosa also served as the executive officer of the Directorate for Human Resource and Doctrine Development (HRDD). A few days before the [[Philippine general election, 2016|May 9, 2016 Philippine general election]], Dela Rosa was relieved as brigade commander of the Reactionary Standby Support Force (RSSF) of the Philippine National Police allegedly due to his [[Facebook]] posts seen to be in favor of then presidential candidate [[Rodrigo Duterte]]. A Facebook status posted on May 1, 2016 which had gone [[Viral phenomenon|viral]] read: {{quote|I am the Brigade Commander of the PNP RSSF composed of 8 battalions close to 5,000 personnel based in Camp Crame. ''Kayong mga mangdadaya at mangliligalig ngayong'' ("those who would cheat and terrorize on the") May 9 elections, ''humanda na kayo'' ("be warned")! WE WILL CRUSH YOU!!!}} Another Facebook post dated April 26, 2016 said: {{quote|It’s time for Batman vs Emilio Aguinaldo. Who will win? The fictional superhero or the real Filipino hero?}} During the [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Luzon leg]], the third and final presidential debate, Duterte said that his main campaign donor was [[Emilio Aguinaldo]], while [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]] standard-bearer [[Mar Roxas]] quoted [[Batman]]. However, Dela Rosa's commanding officer at that time, PNP deputy chief for operations Deputy Director General Danilo Constantino, denied that Dela Rosa's Facebook posts were the main reasons why he was relieved of his duty. According to [[Police rank#Philippines|Deputy Director General]] Constantino, [[Police rank#Philippines|Chief Superintendent]] Dela Rosa was relieved from the Reactionary Standby Support Force (RSSF) so that he could focus on his responsibilities as executive officer of the PNP Directorate for Human Resource and Doctrine Development (HRDD). Nonetheless, Constantino stated that the PNP Internal Affairs Service will investigate Dela Rosa's Facebook posts for possible administrative liabilities as the officers of the Philippine National Police are required to be neutral and apolitical during the elections.{{cite news|last1=Mellejor/Carillo|first1=Ayan/Lovely|title=Davao’s The Rock ‘bato’ and Vin Diesel Gen. Dela Rosa relieved (May 4, 2016)|url=http://mindanaodailymirror.com/davaos-rock-bato-vin-diesel-gen-dela-rosa-relieved-16846/|work=The Mindanao Daily Mirror|accessdate=28 July 2016|date=4 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Felipe|first1=Cecille Suerte|title=Police general axed for FB posts on presidential bet|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/headlines/2016/05/04/1579680/police-general-axed-fb-posts-presidential-bet|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=''The Philippine Star''|date=May 4, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Pro-Duterte cop faces probe for FB posts|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/nation/05/03/16/pro-duterte-cop-faces-probe-for-fb-posts|accessdate=7 February 2017|agency=ABS-CBN News|date=3 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Cudis|first1=Christine Joice C.|title=Ex-Davao City police chief relieved|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/davao/local-news/2016/05/04/ex-davao-city-police-chief-relieved-471611|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=Sun.Star Davao|date=May 4, 2016}} ===PNP Chief, 2016–2018=== [[File:President Duterte with PNP Chief Bato 081616.jpg|right|thumb|President Rodrigo Duterte meeting with [[Philippine National Police|PNP]] Police Director General Ronald dela Rosa in the [[Malacañan Palace]], August 2016. ]] Dela Rosa was handpicked by then presumptive President Rodrigo Duterte as the new PNP Chief on May 19, 2016.{{cite web|last1=Felipe|first1=Cecile Suerte|title=Davao’s ‘The Rock’ is next PNP chief|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/05/19/1584752/davaos-rock-next-pnp-chief|website=Philstar Global|accessdate=23 July 2016|publisher=''The Philippine Star''|date=May 19, 2016}} On July 1, 2016, he was officially sworn in as the 21st chief of the [[Philippine National Police]] while being promoted to Director-General, the highest-ranked PNP officer. In October 2017, Dela Rosa accused Vice President [[Leni Robredo]] of having political ambitions to become president despite still working in her current job. After a few days, he hinted that he himself may run for president in 2022 and would double the pay of police officers if elected. http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/938266/bato-dela-rosa-vice-president-leni-robredo-duterte-presidential-ambition-destabilization-politicshttp://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/10/30/1753932/bato-dela-rosa-hints-possible-presidential-bid He was set to retire on January 21 due to the mandatory retirement at age 56, but his term was extended for 3 months until April 21, 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/14/1768253/bato-dela-rosa-gets-3-more-months-bucor-post|title=Bato dela Rosa gets 3 more months before BuCor post|last=|first=|date=|work=The Philippine Star|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ===Director General of the Bureau of Corrections: April 30, 2018 – October 12, 2018=== On April 30, 2018, Dela Rosa was appointed as Director General of the [[Bureau of Corrections (Philippines)|Bureau of Corrections]]. The appointment document was released publicly on May 3.{{cite news|last1=Corrales|first1=Nestor|title=Dela Rosa officially appointed as BuCor chief|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/987399/bato-dela-rosa-official-appointment-bucor-pnp-bureau-of-corrections-director-general|accessdate=7 May 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=3 May 2018}} == Personal life == Dela Rosa has been married to Nancy Johnson Comandante since 1989, and they have three children together.{{cite news|title=God, wife, ghosts spook not-so-fearless ‘Bato’|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/07/07/16/god-wife-ghosts-spook-not-so-fearless-bato|accessdate=8 February 2017|agency=''ABS-CBN News''|date=7 July 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Takumi|first1=Rie|title=PNP chief is tough on criminals but has a soft side, too|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/574496/news/nation/pnp-chief-is-tough-on-criminals-but-has-a-soft-side-too|accessdate=8 February 2017|agency=''GMA News''|date=July 20, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Caballero|first1=Angelo|title=PNP chief Bato's son seeks to follow dad's footsteps|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/30/16/pnp-chief-batos-son-seeks-to-follow-dads-footsteps|accessdate=8 February 2017|agency=''ABS-CBN News Davao''|date=October 30, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Farolan|first1=Ramon|title=Ronald and Nancy at the White House|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/95387/ronald-nancy-white-house|accessdate=2 May 2017|publisher=''Philippine Daily Inquirer''|date=June 27, 2016}} During his wedding, then-Davao City Mayor [[Rodrigo Duterte]] stood as one of the [[Marriage and wedding customs in the Philippines#Ceremonial sponsors, witnesses, and participants|principal sponsors]]. Duterte and Dela Rosa had known each other since 1986.{{cite news|last1=Gita|first1=Ruth Abbey|title=Dela Rosa assumes post as PNP chief|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2016/07/01/dela-rosa-assumes-post-pnp-chief-482680|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=''SunStar Manila''|date=July 1, 2016}} He has described Duterte as "the greatest influence" in his career. In May 2017, dela Rosa’s only son, Rock, entered the [[Philippine National Police Academy]] as a cadet.{{cite news|last1=Felipe|first1=Cecille Suerte|title=Bato’s only son now a PNPA cadet|url=http://www.philstar.com/metro/2017/05/02/1695817/batos-only-son-now-pnpa-cadet|accessdate=9 May 2017|publisher=''The Philippine Star''|date=May 2, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Anak ni Bato: Rock dela Rosa joins PNPA|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/05/01/17/anak-ni-bato-rock-dela-rosa-joins-pnpa|accessdate=9 May 2017|publisher=''ABS-CBN News''|date=May 1, 2017}} On June 19, 2017, dela Rosa was the guest of honor and speaker at the celebration of [[José Rizal]]’s 156th birth anniversary. He claimed that he was related to the [[National hero of the Philippines|national hero]] through a common ancestor named Ines dela Rosa.{{cite news|last1=De Jesus|first1=Julliane Love|title=Dela Rosa says he’s a ‘proud descendant’ of Jose Rizal|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/906733/dela-rosa-says-hes-a-proud-descendant-of-jose-rizal|accessdate=6 July 2017|publisher=''Philippine Daily Inquirer''|date=June 19, 2017}} Dela Rosa is a [[Catholicism|Catholic]].{{cite news|last1=Bolando|first1=AJ|title=Bato to bishops: I can talk to God without you|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/02/06/1669616/bato-bishops-i-can-talk-god-without-you|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=February 6, 2017}} In a June 2016 radio interview on [[DZMM]], Dela Rosa mentioned that he frequently goes to [[confessional|confession]] to seek forgiveness after he has killed criminals, declaring that he is "no cold-blooded killer".{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/06/10/16/bato-i-am-no-cold-blooded-killer |title=Bato: I am no cold-blooded killer |work=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]] |date=June 10, 2016 |accessdate=August 19, 2016}} Since he became the PNP chief, he has appeared or guested in several TV shows, most notably in the ''Trabahula'' segment of [[ABS-CBN]]'s noontime variety show, [[It's Showtime (variety show)|''It's Showtime'']],{{cite news|title=WATCH: New PNP chief visits 'It's Showtime' (July 21, 2016)|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/07/21/16/watch-new-pnp-chief-visits-its-showtime|accessdate=28 July 2016|agency=[[ABS-CBN News]]}} and [[GMA Network|GMA]]'s sunday variety show, ''[[Sunday PinaSaya]]'' where he met Rodney "Dugong" Juterte, President Rodrigo Duterte's comedic impersonator portrayed by [[Jose Manalo]].{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/576808/showbiz/chikaminute/bato-dela-rosa-nakaharap-si-rodney-juterte|title=Bato dela Rosa, nakaharap si Rodney Juterte|publisher=[[GMA News]]|date=August 8, 2016|accessdate=August 8, 2016}} Dela Rosa is a longtime fan of [[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] team [[Barangay Ginebra San Miguel]].{{cite news|url=http://www.spin.ph/basketball/pba/news/pnp-chief-ronald-bato-dela-rosa-long-time-die-hard-ginebra-fan-sees-kings-ending-their-long-title-drought-|title=As a Ginebra fan, PNP chief Ronald 'Bato' Dela Rosa is as solid as a rock|publisher=[[Sports Interactive Network Philippines]]|last=Ramos|first=Gerry|date=October 7, 2016|accessdate=October 16, 2016}} == See also == * [[Philippine Drug {{Expand Russian|Песнь о Синклере|date=April 2018}} "'''Sinclairvisan'''" or "'''Sinclairsvisan'''" ("The Sinclair Song") is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[propaganda song]] with 90 verses, written by [[Anders Odel]] in 1739 to the "[[La Folia]]" melody. The song describes the murder of the Swedish [[diplomat]], ''[[friherre]]'', and [[major]] [[Malcolm Sinclair (Swedish nobleman)|Malcolm Sinclair]]. Sinclair was murdered in 1739, while on a diplomatic mission, by two Russian officers acting on orders from the Russian government.
==Synopsis== The song is narrated by the shepherd Celadon, who describes how he is brought by a "strange old man" into the [[Elysium|Elysian Fields]]. He watches as the murdered Sinclair enters a great castle, where he is greeted by 12 kings ("twelve Swedish Carls", i.e. [[Mythological kings of Sweden|Charles I]]–[[Charles XII of Sweden|XII]]), to whom he relates the circumstances of his death.
==Authorship== The song is included as an uncharacteristic entry in [[Erik Gustaf Geijer]] and [[Arvid August Afzelius]]'s influential folk song collection ''[[Svenska folk-visor från forntiden]]''. According to the authors, the song was popularly held to have been penned by [[Jacob Henrik Mörk]], author of ''Adelriks och Giöthildas äfwentyr'' (1742-44), until a draft of the song was found among Odel's manuscripts. They also note that older publications of the song include an epilogue, in which the ''A'' and ''O'' in "Celadon" are emphasized, hinting at the author's initials.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Geijer |first1=Erik Gustaf |author-link1=Erik Gustaf Geijer |last2=Afzelius |first2=Arvid August |author-link2=Arvid August Afzelius |year=1814 |chapter=Malcom Sinclair |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/svenskafolkviso02geijgoog#page/n272/mode/2up |title=Svenska folk-visor från forntiden |url= |dead-url= |format= |language=Swedish |volume=1 |location=Stockholm |publisher=Strinnholm och Häggström |publication-date= |pages=220-243 |oclc=23555964 |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date= 15 April 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox MMA event | name = Strikeforce: Cormier vs. Mir | image = StrikeforcePosterCormierMir1.jpg | promotion = [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)|Strikeforce]] | date = Cancelled | venue = [[Chesapeake Energy Arena]] | city = [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], United States | gate = | attendance = | previousevent= [[Strikeforce: Melendez vs. Healy]] |followingevent= [[Strikeforce: Marquardt vs. Saffiedine]] }} '''''Strikeforce: Cormier vs. Mir''''' was a planned [[mixed martial arts]] event that was to be held by [[Strikeforce (mixed martial arts)|Strikeforce]]. The event was scheduled to take place on November 3, 2012 at the [[Chesapeake Energy Arena]] in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]].<ref name="sf1">{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/30489/strikeforce-heads-to-oklahoma-city-for-daniel-cormier-vs-frank-mir.mma|title=USA TODAY: Strikeforce heads to Oklahoma City for Daniel Cormier vs. Frank Mir|publisher=MMAjunkie.com|date=2012-09-03|accessdate=2012-09-03|last=Morgan|first=John|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108025752/http://mmajunkie.com/news/30489/strikeforce-heads-to-oklahoma-city-for-daniel-cormier-vs-frank-mir.mma|archivedate=2012-11-08|df=}}</ref><ref name="sf2">{{cite web|url= http://www.mmafighting.com/2012/9/3/3289620/first-ufc-vs-strikeforce-match-looks-to-be-early-november-in-oklahoma |title=Strikeforce: Mir vs. Cormier Heavyweights |publisher=MMAFighting.com |date=2012-09-03 |accessdate=2012-09-03 |last=Meltzer |first=Dave}}</ref>
==Background== The main event was expected to be see Strikeforce Heavyweight Grand Prix champion [[Daniel Cormier]] face former UFC Heavyweight Champion [[Frank Mir]].<ref name="sf1"/><ref name="sf2"/> However, Mir was forced to withdraw due to injury. Though fellow UFC fighters [[Matt Mitrione]] (who declined the fight) & [[Pat Barry (fighter)|Pat Barry]] were possible replacements for Mir,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/30688/frank-mir-injured-out-of-strikeforce-heavyweight-fight-against-daniel-cormier.mma|title=Frank Mir injured, out of Strikeforce heavyweight fight against Daniel Cormier|publisher=MMAjunkie.com|date=2012-09-19|accessdate=2012-09-19|last=Marrocco|first=Steven}}</ref> the bout was eventually cancelled. The Cormier/Mir bout would eventually take place at [[UFC on Fox: Henderson vs. Melendez]] in April 2013, following Strikeforce's closure and Cormier's signing with the UFC. In the rescheduled match-up, Cormier won by unanimous decision.
A middleweight championship bout between champion [[Luke Rockhold]] and [[Lorenz Larkin]] was originally scheduled for this event,<ref name="staff">{{cite web|url=http://www.ufc.com/news/SF5-venue-news|title=Strikeforce Heads to OKC with Cormier vs. Mir, Rockhold vs. Larkin November 3|publisher=UFC.com|date=2012-09-04|author=staff}}</ref> but was called off due to an injury to Rockhold. The bout was rescheduled for the promotion's last event [[Strikeforce: Marquardt vs. Saffiedine]] in January 2013, but both Rockhold and Larkin were replaced by [[Ronaldo Souza]] and UFC middleweight [[Ed Herman (mixed martial artist)|Ed Herman]] due to their own respective injuries.
On October 12, 2012, Strikeforce announced it was cancelling this event, the second in a row. Injuries to headliner Frank Mir, as well as co-headliner and middleweight champion [[Luke Rockhold]] were cited as the deciding factors for the cancellation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/31099/strikeforce-cancels-nov-3-event-in-oklahoma-city-plans-january-return.mma|title=Strikeforce cancels Nov. 3 event in Oklahoma City, plans January return|publisher=MMAjunkie.com|date=2012-10-12|last=Stupp|first=Dann|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109000532/http://mmajunkie.com/news/31099/strikeforce-cancels-nov-3-event-in-oklahoma-city-plans-january-return.mma|archivedate=2012-11-09|df=}}</ref> Following the cancellation, the bout between [[Tim Kennedy (fighter)|Tim Kennedy]] & [[Trevor Smith (fighter)|Trevor Smith]] was rescheduled for [[Strikeforce: Marquardt vs. Saffiedine]] in January 2013, where Kennedy won via third round submission.
== Cancelled fight card ==
=== Main card (Showtime) === *'''Middleweight bout: [[Tim Kennedy (fighter)|Tim Kennedy]] vs. [[Trevor Smith (fighter)|Trevor Smith]]'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/30718/tim-kennedy-meets-trevor-smith-at-strikeforces-november-show-in-oklahoma-city.mma|title=Tim Kennedy meets Trevor Smith at Strikeforce's November show in Oklahoma City|publisher=MMAjunkie.com|date=2012-09-20|author=staff}}</ref> *'''Lightweight bout: [[Jorge Masvidal]] vs. [[Bobby Green (fighter)|Bobby Green]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/30681/bobby-green-vs-jorge-masvidal-targeted-for-strikeforce-cormier-vs-mir.mma|title=Bobby Green vs. Jorge Masvidal targeted for 'Strikeforce:Cormier vs. Mir'|publisher=MMAjunkie.com|date=2012-09-18|author=staff}}</ref> *'''Middleweight Championship bout: [[Luke Rockhold]] (c) vs. [[Lorenz Larkin]]''''''<ref name="staff"/> *'''Heavyweight bout: [[Daniel Cormier]] vs. [[Frank Mir]]'''

[[File:Teatro Argentino de La Plata.jpg|thumb|250px|Teatro Argentino de La Plata]][[File:La Plata - Postal Teatro Argentino - 1904.jpg|thumb|250px|The former Teatro Argentino (1904)]] The '''Teatro Argentino de La Plata''' is the second most important lyric [[List of opera houses|opera house]] in Argentina, after the [[Teatro Colón]] in [[Buenos Aires]]. The theatre is located in a central block of the city of [[La Plata]], the capital of [[Buenos Aires Province]]. The venue occupies the block bounded by the 9 and 10 streets and 51 & 53 avenues; it belongs to the ''Monumental Axis'' of public buildings in La Plata.
==The original building==
The original building was a classic Italian opera house, conceived in renaissance style by the Italian architect [[Leopoldo Rocchi]]. Construction began in 1887, five years after the foundation of the city of [[La Plata]] itself. The main hall had a capacity of ''ca.'' 1,500 seats. It was inaugurated on November 19, 1890, with [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s ''[[Otello]]''; in leading roles were the Italian soprano [[Elvira Colonnese]] (Desdemona) and the Uruguayan tenor [[José Oxilia]] (Othello). The theatre grew to accommodate a renowned stable orchestra and chorus. A stable ballet company was added in 1946. Among the great artists that performed at the Teatro Argentino we find singers such as [[Maria Barrientos]], [[Luisa Tetrazzini]], [[Marian Anderson]], [[Emma Carelli]], [[Fedora Barbieri]], [[Tito Schipa]], [[Beniamino Gigli]], [[Titta Ruffo]], and [[Mario del Monaco]], classical ballet dancers such as [[Anna Pavlova]], [[Dore Hoyer]] and [[Iris Scaccheri]], as well as musicians such as [[Pietro Mascagni]], [[Richard Strauss]] (with the [[Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra]]), [[Arthur Rubinstein]], [[Andrés Segovia]], [[Alexander Brailowsky]], [[Claudio Arrau]], [[Pablo Casals]], and [[Yehudi Menuhin]].
==The New Building==
Unfortunately, a major fire destroyed the original building in 1977, leaving only the badly damaged exterior walls standing. Against national and international outcry, the ''de facto'' government of the military dictatorship at the time (the so-called ''[[Proceso de Reorganizacion Nacional]]'') decided against rebuilding the original classic structure. Instead, it chose to replace it with a massive Theatre & Cultural Centre designed in a [[brutalist]] style, located on the same city block. During the intervening years (1977–1999), the Teatro Argentino companies continued to produce performances in various La Plata venues, notably the former [[movie theatre]], the Cine Gran Rocha. After much planning and rescheduling due to economic difficulties, the new building was finished and inaugurated on October 12, 1999 with a performance that included excerpts from works of [[Giuseppe Verdi]], [[Charles Gounod]], [[Umberto Giordano]] and [[Gaetano Donizetti]], as well as the ballet ''Tango en gris'' ("Tango in grey"), with music by [[Atilio Stampone]] and ''régie'' by [[Oscar Araiz]].<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/1999/10/13/e-04001d.htm Gala Night in the Return of the Teatro Argentino de La Plata] ''Clarin'' newspaper {{es icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/Archivo/Nota.asp?nota_id=157229 Dance and Opera for a Historic Day] ''La Nacion'' newspaper {{es}}</ref>
The new complex includes today a 2,000-seat operatic venue with a typical European horseshoe structure, named [[Alberto Ginastera]] Hall after the famous Argentine composer. An enormous three-tonne bronze chandelier with 400 light-bulbs hangs over the main floor, in an exact replica of the one featured in the original building.
The complex also includes the smaller 300-seat [[Ástor Piazzolla]] Hall, as well as rehearsal areas, and space for the associated technical shops. The lower level includes the [[Emilio Pettoruti]] Exhibition Hall for permanent and transient art collections.
Despite the excellent technical facilities and the superb acoustics of the main hall, the complex itself, built in [[brutalist]] style, continues to be regarded as a sort of eyesore by the local population.<ref>“El Teatro Argentino: La construcción actual perdió el estilo de la obra original]” Diario Hoy, 24 October 2003, 24.</ref>

United Kingdom |language = English |budget = }} '''''The Attic: The Hiding of Anne Frank ''''' is a 1988 [[television film]] directed by [[John Erman]], based on [[Miep Gies]]'s book ''Anne Frank Remembered''. The film was broadcast as part of an ad hoc network, [[Fourth television network#Golden Showcase Network|Kraft Golden Showcase Network]].{{cite news|last1=Key|first1=Janet|title=Despite Mega-budget, Att Sees Real Bargain In `The Final Days`|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-11-01/business/8901270292_1_program-hour-final-days|accessdate=April 25, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 1, 1989}} Playwright [[William Hanley]] received an [[Emmy]] for his script.Dennis Heves, "William Hanley, Playwright and TV Writer, Dies at 80. ''New York Times'', June 3, 2012. [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/04/theater/william-hanley-playwright-and-tv-writer-dies-at-80.html]< ==Plot== In 1940, the [[Nazis]] invade the Netherlands. [[Miep Gies]] is a young woman, and an office assistant of [[Otto Frank]], who is [[Jewish]]. As the Nazis begin to kill the Jews, Otto Frank becomes worried about his family. In July 1942, Otto Frank decides to hide his family after his daughter [[Margot Frank|Margot]] is called to appear for transport to a Nazi labor camp. Miep, who is trusted by Otto, hides them in the attic above the office, that was called [[Anne Frank House|The Annexe]]. The film tells the true story of Gies' struggle to keep the family hidden and safe, as the Nazis turn Amsterdam upside-down. A few days later, the van Daans join the Franks in hiding, and after some months [[Fritz Pfeffer|Albert Dussel]], a Jewish dentist, joins them in hiding. Miep, her husband [[Jan Gies]], along with Miep's fellow office workers [[Victor Kugler|Mr Kraler]], [[Johannes Kleiman|Mr Koophuis]], and [[Bep Voskuijl|Elli]] actively helps the innocent Jews to hide. Miep is never able to keep these hiders out of her thoughts, and she does her best to protect them. But all her efforts are destroyed on August 4, 1944. The [[Gestapo]] is informed about the hiders, and they come to the building to arrest them. Mr Kraler and Mr Koophuis are arrested with the hiders, while Miep is spared because she is [[Austrians|Austrian]] (which was pro-Nazi since the [[Anschluss]] took over in 1938, the year before the war started as it is German-speaking and the birthplace of [[Hitler]]) as well as a [[Gentile]], and [[Karl Silberbauer]], the Gestapo officer who arrested the hiders, was also an Austrian Gentile. So, out of mercy, Silberbauer spares Miep. After the arrest, Miep and Jan go to the annex, and Miep finds [[Anne Frank]]'s diary in the floor of Anne's room, and she collects it before the Annex is emptied by the Nazis. A day later, Miep decides to bribe Silberbauer in return of her friends, but Silberbauer denies. The war is finished a few months later, and Otto Frank safely returns to Amsterdam. Miep and Jan shelter him. Otto tells Miep that [[Edith Frank|Mrs Frank]] had died in the [[Auschwitz]] concentration camp, and [[Hermann van Pels|Mr van Daan]] was gassed by the Nazis in Auschwitz. However, Anne, Margot and [[Auguste van Pels|Mrs van Daan]] were sent to the [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]] concentration camp, which was not a death camp, and Otto has high hopes for them. But a few days later, a letter comes to Otto informing him that Anne and Margot died in Bergen-Belsen. Otto tells Miep, who is distraught. Miep takes Anne's diary, which she has not read, from her drawer and gives it to Otto Frank. While Otto reads Anne's diary, Miep goes to Anne's room in the hiding place, and sits in a chair. She then leaves the building, and the films ends with her cycling home, as we hear her speak in a voice-over. ==Cast== *[[Mary Steenburgen]] – [[Miep Gies]] *[[Paul Scofield]] – [[Otto Frank]] *[[Lisa Jacobs (actress)| Lisa Jacobs]] – [[Anne Frank]] *[[Huub Stapel]] – [[Jan Gies]] *[[Eleanor Bron]] – [[Edith Frank]] *[[Frances Cuka]] – [[Auguste van Pels|Petronella Van Daan]] *[[Victor Spinetti]] – [[Hermann van Pels|Herman Van Daan]] *[[Miriam Karlin]] – Mrs. Samson *Ian Sears – [[Peter van Pels|Peter van Daan]] *[[Georgia Slowe]] – [[Margot Frank]] *[[Isabelle Amyes]] – [[Bep Voskuijl|Elli Vossen]] *[[Ronald Pickup]] – [[Johannes Kleiman|Mr. Jo Koophuis]] *[[Gary Raymond]] – [[Victor Kugler|Mr. Victor Kraler]] *Jeffrey Robert – [[Fritz Pfeffer|Dr. Albert Dussel]] *Edda Barends – Charlotte Kaletta (Lotte Dussel) *[[Tom Wilkinson]] – [[Karl Silberbauer]] ==Awards== [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, Movie or a Dramatic Special]] (1988) ==See also== *''[[The Diary of Anne Frank (1959 film)|The Diary of Anne Frank]]'' (1959 film) *''[[Anne Frank: The Whole Story]]'' (2001 mini-series) *[[People associated with Anne Frank]] *[[List of Holocaust films]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0094685|title=The Attic: The Hiding of Anne Frank}} {{Anne Frank}} {{Anne Frank in other forms}} {{John Erman}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Attic, The: The Hiding Of Anne Frank}} [[Category:1988 television films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British television films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about Anne Frank]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films directed by John Erman]] [[Category:Holocaust films]] [[Category:Peabody Award-winning broadcasts]]

''[[AfterMASH]]'' }} '''''W*A*L*T*E*R''''' is a failed 1984 [[television pilot]] for a [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'' that was never picked up. It starred [[Gary Burghoff]], who reprised his ''M*A*S*H'' character. The episode relates the adventures of [[List of M*A*S*H characters#Radar O.27Reilly|Corporal Walter "Radar" O'Reilly]] after he returns home from the [[Korean War]]. He is no longer calling himself "Radar" and has moved away from [[Iowa]] after he sent his mother to live with his aunt. Settling in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], by the beginning of the series he has become a police officer, though his character is still as in the original series.David Scott Diffrient, ''M*A*S*H'' ([[Wayne State University Press]], 2008), {{ISBN|978-0814335529}}, p. 142. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CAdN-I5KqFUC&lpg=PT150&dq=W*A*L*T*E*R%20burghoff&pg=PT150#v=onepage&q=W*A*L*T*E*R%20&f=false Excerpts available] at [[Google Books]].Vincent Terrace, ''Encyclopedia of Television Pilots, 1937-2012'' ([[McFarland & Company]], 2013), {{ISBN|978-1476602493}}, p. 316. [https://books.google.com/books?id=XxTx1xK-q14C&lpg=PP1&dq=W*A*L*T*E*R%20burghoff%201984&pg=PA316#v=onepage&q=W*A*L*T*E*R%20burghoff%201984&f=false Excerpts available] at [[Google Books]].{{cite web|author=Maçek III, J.C.|title=What Happens When Happy Shows Turn All X-Files on You?|date=12 January 2017|work=[[PopMatters]]|url=http://www.popmatters.com/column/what-happens-when-happy-shows-turn-all-x-files-on-you/}} ==Plot== The episode opens with Walter O'Reilly in his cousin Wendell Micklejohn's apartment. They are getting ready for their workday while watching the start of a television interview. The interview shows journalist [[Clete Roberts]] following up on the members of the M*A*S*H 4077th. The previous week Roberts had interviewed [[Hawkeye Pierce]], and this week he is catching up with O'Reilly. At the police department and through store windows on the street, O'Reilly and Micklejohn catch pieces of the television interview, giving viewers of the pilot a chance to sample the potential series and to build a bridge between the events of ''M*A*S*H'' and ''W*A*L*T*E*R''. Viewers learn that O'Reilly returned to [[Iowa]], where he failed at farming. He sold the farm and the livestock and sent his mother off to live with his aunt. His bride left him for another man during their honeymoon. O'Reilly decided to commit suicide, and went to a drug store to buy sleeping pills for an overdose (as well as aspirin, because sleeping pills give him headaches). The drugstore clerk, Victoria, cheered him up and they became good friends. His cousin Wendell helped him get a job on the police force. Walter solves a dispute between two strippers, and gets his wallet back from a young would-be thief whose father had died in Korea.{{cite web|url =http://www.bestcareanywhere.net/walter.htm|title =W*A*L*T*E*R|accessdate = 2013-08-21|date = 2006-06-02|publisher = Best Care Anywhere }} ==Cast== * [[Gary Burghoff]] as Walter O'Reilly * [[Ray Buktenica]] as Wendell Micklejohn * [[Victoria Jackson]] as Victoria * [[Noble Willingham]] as Sergeant Sowell * [[Meeno Peluce]] as Elston Krennick * [[Clete Roberts]] as The Interviewer * [[Sam Scarber]] as Haskell * [[Lyman Ward (actor)|Lyman Ward]] as Bigelow * [[Sarah Abrell]] as Judith Crane * [[Larry Cedar]] as Zipkin * [[Francine Gable]] as Pretty Girl * [[Victoria Carroll]] as Bubbles Sincere * June Berry as Dixie Devoe * [[Bobby Ramsen]] as The Singer * [[Dick Miller]] as The Theater Owner ==Production== ===Timeline=== The episode takes place after the series finale of ''M*A*S*H'', and a two part guest appearance on ''[[AfterMASH]]'', in which Radar was forced to leave the family farm. ===Broadcast difficulties=== Since the pilot was never picked up by [[CBS]] as a series, it was shown as a "CBS [[Television special|Special]] Presentation" on July 17, 1984. It was shown once in the Eastern and [[Central time zone]]s of the United States, but pre-empted on the West Coast by [[CBS News]] coverage of the [[1984 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]]. This is the only known broadcast of the pilot.{{cite web|url = http://www.tvobscurities.com/articles/walter/|title =W*A*L*T*E*R|accessdate = 2013-08-20|date = 2005-02-15|publisher = Television Obscurities }} ==References== ==External links== {{Portal|M*A*S*H}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OS8Vd1vVqXc Full pilot] * {{IMDb title|id=0203189|title=W*A*L*T*E*R}} * [http://www.tvobscurities.com/articles/walter/ Television Obscurities – ''W*A*L*T*E*R''] {{Mash}} {{DEFAULTSORT:WALTER}} [[Category:1984 American television episodes]] [[Category:American television pilots]] [[Category:American television spin-offs]] [[Category:Television pilots not picked up as a series]] [[Category:M*A*S*H]] [[Category:Television series by 20th Century Fox Television]] [[Category:Comedy television episode stubs]] [[Category:Television films by 20th Century Fox Television]] [[Category:Films directed by Bill Bixby]] [[Category:July 1984 events]]

{{crw|WIN}} (1 each) | most runs = | most wickets = | current = [[2017 Women's Cricket World Cup Qualifier]] }} The '''ICC Women's Cricket World Cup Qualifier''' is an international [[cricket]] tournament that serves as the final step of the qualification process for the [[Women's Cricket World Cup]]. The Women's World Cup was first held [[1973 Women's Cricket World Cup|in 1973]], and for the first seven editions participation was determined solely by invitation, issued at the discretion of the [[International Women's Cricket Council]] (IWCC).[http://womenscrickethistory.org/History/iwcc_15.html International Women's Cricket Council (IWCC): Fifteenth Meeting] – Women's Cricket History. Retrieved 3 October 2015. A qualification tournament was first held [[2003 IWCC Trophy|in 2003]] (for the [[2005 Women's Cricket World Cup|2005 World Cup]]), which was hosted by the Netherlands and won by [[Ireland women's cricket team|Ireland]].[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/3/International_Womens_Cricket_Council_Trophy_2003.html International Women's Cricket Council Trophy 2003] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 8 December 2015. Three subsequent tournaments have been held – [[2008 Women's Cricket World Cup Qualifier|in 2008]], hosted by South Africa and won by [[Pakistan women's national cricket team|Pakistan]]; [[2011 Women's Cricket World Cup Qualifier|in 2011]], hosted by Bangladesh and won by the [[West Indies women's cricket team|West Indies]]; and [[2017 Women's Cricket World Cup Qualifier|in 2017]], hosted by Sri Lanka and won by [[India women's national cricket team|India]].[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/6/ICC_Womens_World_Cup_Qualifying_Series_2007-08.html ICC Women's World Cup Qualifying Series 2007/08] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 8 December 2015.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/15/ICC_Womens_World_Cup_Qualifying_Series_2011-12.html ICC Women's World Cup Qualifying Series 2011/12] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 8 December 2015. The inaugural event in 2003 was organised by the IWCC and branded as the '''IWCC Trophy'''. The IWCC was subsumed by the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) in 2005, and all other editions have been known simply as the World Cup Qualifier. The number of teams and qualifying places has varied at each tournament – in 2003, six teams competed for two qualifying spots, while at the next edition (in 2008) eight teams contested two qualifying spots. The 2011 event saw ten teams compete for three qualifying places, and the 2017 tournament featured ten teams and four qualifying places.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/28158473 |title=World Cup 2017: Women's Championship will form qualifying |accessdate=30 June 2015 |work=BBC Sport}} ==Results== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; width: 100%; text-align: center;" |- ! rowspan=2 width=10%|Year ! rowspan=2 width=15%|Host(s) ! rowspan=2 width=15%|Final venue ! colspan=3|Final |- ! width=18%|Winner ! width=24%|Result ! width=18%|Runner-up |- style="background:#ddeeff" | [[2003 IWCC Trophy|2003]] | {{flag|Netherlands}} | no final | {{crw|IRE}}

{{UDP|date=January 2018}}'''The Yidan Prize''' (/ji: ‘dan/） is an educational prize founded in 2016 by [[Chen Yidan|Dr. Charles Chen]]. The prize is awarded each year to two individuals or organizations whose work has made profound contributions to education [[research]] and development. The prize comprises two categories: the Yidan Prize for Education Research, which recognizes outstanding research that makes significant contributions to education, and the Yidan Prize for Education Development, which recognizes innovative ideas that tackle pressing challenges in the field of education.
The prize is financed and governed by a HK$2.5 billion (about US$320 million) independent trust. Each prize carries an award of HK$30 million (about US$3.87 million)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-38639891|title=Chinese billionaire offers biggest education prize - BBC|website=www.bbc.com|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref> – half cash award and half project fund – as well as a gold medal. Through a series of initiatives, the prize serves to provide a platform that allows the global community to engage in conversation around education and to play a role in education philanthropy.
Nominees can be either individuals or teams of up to three representatives, who can be teachers, researchers, academics, policy makers and advocates among others. The two independent judging panels will screen valid nominations and select a candidate for each prize category. Candidates are assessed on four criteria: [[future orientation]], [[innovation]], transformation and [[sustainability]].
The Yidan Prize unveiled its inaugural laureates on 19 September 2017 in [[Hong Kong]]. They are [[Carol Dweck|Carol S. Dweck]] of Stanford University and [[Vicky Colbert]],<ref>https://ie-today.co.uk/Article/carol-dweck-and-vicky-colbert-win-largest-education-prize</ref> founder and director of Fundación Escuela Nueva. At the inaugural Yidan Prize Award Presentation Ceremony and the Yidan Prize Summit, they shared their ground-breaking work in education.
== History == The prize was established in 2016 by the Yidan Prize Foundation. [[Chen Yidan]] (English name Charles Chen), established the foundation and the prize to promote educational causes globally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/chinese-billionaire-seeks-ideas-from-canadian-universities-for-education-prize/article33469746|title=Chinese billionaire seeks ideas from Canadian universities for education prize - The Globe and Mail|website=www.theglobeandmail.com|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.mit.edu/2016/yidan-prize-for-education-research-and-development-announced-1031|title=Yidan Prize for Education Research and Education Development announced at MIT - MIT News|website=www.news.mit.edu.com|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref>
The first prize winners were announced during September 2017 and the first award ceremony took place during December 2017 in Hong Kong.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.stanford.edu/2017/09/19/stanford-psychologist-recognized-4-million-prize/|title=Stanford psychologist recognized with $4 million prize {{!}} Stanford News|last=University|first=Stanford|date=2017-09-19|work=Stanford News|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/russellflannery/2017/12/10/stanford-columbia-educators-win-first-yidan-prizes-from-tencent-co-founder/#6087bae0163a|title=Stanford, Colombia Educators Win Tencent Co-Founder's First Yidan Prizes|last=Flannery|first=Russell|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}</ref> The two 2018 laureates were [[Anant Agarwal]]<ref>https://www.chronicle.com/article/It-s-Time-for-Colleges-to/244539</ref><ref>http://news.mit.edu/2018/anant-agarwal-mit-professor-edx-ceo-wins-yidan-prize-0918</ref><ref name=A>http://www.atimes.com/article/yidan-prizes-announced-for-supporters-of-education-sector/</ref> and [[Larry Hedges]].<ref name=A /><ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-15/the-billionaire-who-quit-tencent-to-pledge-his-money-to-teachers</ref><ref>https://thefinancialexpress.com.bd/education/yidan-prize-names-2018-laureates-1537173830</ref>
=== The Yidan Prize Foundation === The prize is overseen by the Yidan Prize Foundation. The members of the global advisory board are:
* [[Qian Tang|Dr Qian Tang]], assistant director-general for Education, [[UNESCO]] * Kai-ming Cheng, emeritus professor, the [[University of Hong Kong]] * Dankert Vedeler, assistant director-general of the [[Ministry of Education and Research (Norway)|Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research]]'s Department of Policy Analysis, Lifelong Learning and International Affairs * Manzoor Ahmed, professor emeritus, [[BRAC University]] * Jamil Salmi, former [[World Bank]] tertiary education coordinator * [[Marc Tucker|Marc S. Tucker]], president and chief executive officer, the [[National Center on Education and the Economy]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://yidanprize.org/en/people-gab.php|title=The Yidan Prize Foundation Global Advisory Board - The Yidan Prize|website=www.yidanprize.org|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref>
== Adjudication process == Given on an annual basis, the Yidan Prize recognizes and supports individuals for forward-looking innovations that creates sustainable impacts on the education systems of today and tomorrow. Each nomination is reviewed according to a set of rigorous criteria in order to identify the very best individuals. Projects must be [[sustainability|sustainable]],[[future orientation|future-oriented]], transformative and [[innovation|innovative]].
=== Nominations === The Yidan Prize invites government bodies, non-government organizations and professional associations, and individual thought leaders, to propose nominees. Self-nomination is allowed in exceptional cases. Nominees can be individuals or working teams of up to three people and can be teachers, researchers, academics, policy makers, advocates or those who work in related roles. Posthumous nominations are not accepted but nominees who are not awarded can be nominated again in the future.
=== Judging panels === The Yidan Prize is managed and governed by the Yidan Prize Foundation board of directors, an international judging committee and a global advisory board formed by a respected team of independent and authoritative experts. The [[board of directors]] is responsible for approving the judging committee’s awardee recommendations.
The Judging Committee is responsible for screening nominations and selecting laureates. It comprises two independent judging panels. The committee is composed of:
'''Chairman''': [[Kōichirō Matsuura|Dr Koichiro Matsuura]] - former director-general, UNESCO
'''The Yidan Prize for Education Research Judging Panel'''
* Professor [[Chu Ching-wu|Paul Chu Ching-wu]] - Panel head, Professor of physics, T. L. L. Temple Chair of Science, [[University of Houston]] * Professor [[Bruce Alberts|Bruce M. Alberts]] - Chancellor’s leadership chair in Biochemistry and Biophysics for Science and Education, the [[University of California, San Francisco]] * Professor [[Phillip A. Griffiths]] - professor emeritus of mathematics, the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[New Jersey]]
'''The Yidan Prize for Education Development Judging Panel'''
* [[Dorothy Gordon (Ghana)|Dorothy K. Gordon]] - Panel head, director-general, the [[Ghana-India Kofi Annan Centre of Excellence in ICT]] * Professor [[Steven A. Cohen (academic)|Steven Cohen]] - executive director, [[The Earth Institute]], [[Columbia University]] * Dr Allan E. Goodman - president and chief executive officer, the [[Institute of International Education]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://yidanprize.org/en/people-jc.php|title=The Yidan Prize Foundation Judging Committee - The Yidan Prize|website=www.yidanprize.org|access-date=2017-09-22}}</ref>
== Prizes == The Yidan Prizes consist of a medal as well as a financial award for each recipient. The medals were designed by Kan Tai-keung. They feature a book motif on one side representing important texts in Chinese literature, On the other side, the Yidan Prize Foundation logo is incorporated with scenes of a figure contemplating the horizon near a tree. The financial award of a cash prize of HK$15 million and a project fund of HK$15 million to each of the two top candidates is supported by a US$320 million [[financial endowment|endowment]]. The inaugural laureates for the Yidan Prize, [[Carol Dweck|Dr Carol Dweck]] and [[Vicky Colbert]], were announced on September 19, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/stanford-professor-wins-inaugural-4-million-yidan-prize|title=Stanford professor wins inaugural $4 million Yidan Prize|date=2017-09-19|work=Times Higher Education|access-date=2017-09-21|language=en}}</ref>
== The Worldwide Educating for the Future Index == On September 19, 2017, the Yidan Prize Foundation launched the first Worldwide Educating for the Future Index. The index was commissioned by the Yidan Prize Foundation and conducted by the [[Economist Intelligence Unit]]. It evaluates how 35 developed and developing economies, representing 88% of global GDP and 77% of global population, are preparing the next generation with the skills needed for the future. The index is based on 16 indicators across three thematic categories: education policy, teaching environment and socio-economic environment. It's the world’s first ever comprehensive benchmarking tool that focuses on inputs to education systems, as opposed to outputs such as test scores. The index examines the strengths and weaknesses of education systems for the next generation and creates a blueprint for governments to improve.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/edtechresearcher/2017/10/a_blueprint_for_the_future_of_education_-_the_worldwide_educating_for_the_future_index.html|title=The Worldwide Educating for the Future Index - A Blueprint for Change|website=www.edweek.org|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref>

Once located along Calle Iris (now a part of [[C.M. Recto Avenue]]), [[Manila]], the theatre was named after [[José Zorrilla]] (1817 - 1893), a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] poet and playwright. The building, which had a seating capacity of 900 people, was officially opened on 17 August 1893, and it was the venue for [[Spanish-language]] and Tagalog-language stage performances.{{cite web|url=http://www.retrato.com.ph/photodtl.asp?id=AR00382 |title=Zorrilla Theater |publisher=Filipinas Heritage Library (A Division of Ayala Foundation, Inc.), Retrato.com |accessdate=19 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722141049/http://www.retrato.com.ph/photodtl.asp?id=AR00382 |archivedate=July 22, 2011 }} ==See also== *[[Manila Grand Opera House]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722141049/http://www.retrato.com.ph/photodtl.asp?id=AR00382 1911 photograph of the Zorrilla Theater] at Retrato.com.ph *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110930084904/http://www.retrato.com.ph/photodtl.asp?id=AR00379 Photograph of the interior of the Zorrilla Theater] at Retrato.com.ph *[http://www.himig.com.ph/features/39-bodabil Photograph of the exterior of the Zorrilla Theater] at Himig.com.ph {{coord missing|Philippines}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zorrilla Theater}} [[Category:Former buildings and structures in Manila]] [[Category:Theaters in Manila]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Sampaloc, Manila]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1893]]
